yet nothing is beyond their greatness—
all streams flow to them,
thus they achieve the great.

Light promises must be few in truth—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Speaking without truth,
acting without benevolence,
governing without order,
doing without achievement—
thus the superficial pretenders,
the Five Emperors and Three Kings did not sincerely adhere to the Dao.

Many easinesses bring many difficulties—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Later generations, lacking the roots of governance and teaching,
yet desiring to rule over the myriad people—
this is difficult.

Thus the sages—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Affairs are difficult to complete but easy to ruin,
words are difficult to establish but easy to abandon—
thus the sages focused their hearts on the Dao,
the enlightened saw uniquely in non-action.

Yet difficulties remain,
and thus they are ultimately without difficulty.

*Chapter Sixty-Four on Ease in Holding Firm*

*This chapter of The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* speaks:
The people of the end times indulge in perverse desires and lose their nature—
their movements are never upright.
Governance brings chaos,
self-cultivation brings falsehood.
Those who do not hear the Dao cannot return to rectitude,
those who do not understand virtue/power cannot achieve tranquility.

Human nature is originally without perversity,
yet prolonged indulgence in perversity
makes the easy seem easy and forgets its root—
thus they cling to perversity.
Water’s nature desires clarity,
yet sand and soil defile it;
human nature desires rectitude,
yet perverse speech harms it.

Knowing their own deceit is useless,
even the greedy will reject it,
yet not knowing their own desires are useless,
even the virtuous cannot relinquish them.

Thus men lose their states and die by others’ hands,
becoming the world’s laughter—
they have never failed to indulge their own desires,
thus those who act bring ruin,
those who grasp lose.

Knowing winter fans and summer furs are useless to them,
all things turn to dust and filth—
useless.

Thus it is said:
Non-action, hence no ruin,
non-grasping, hence no loss.

Its ease is easy to hold—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Wisdom discerning right and wrong
is the gateway to calamity and fortune.

Its unmanifested is easy to plan—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Movement and stillness, public and private—
the pivot of gain and harm.

Its fragile is easy to break—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Calamity’s arrival—
men themselves generate it;
fortune’s coming—
men themselves complete it.

Its subtle is easy to disperse—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Accumulating rectitude brings fortune,
accumulating perversity brings calamity.

Doing it before it arises—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Men all neglect minor harms,
easy trivial matters,
until great calamities arrive—
one must be cautious.

Later men know to respond to calamities after they arise,
yet do not know to be cautious in the subtle to prevent calamities from forming.
Preventing calamities from arising is easy,
yet applying remedies after calamities form is difficult.

Curing it before chaos—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The Dao is cautious in the small and subtle,
great calamities do not flourish.
Yet modern men do not strive to be cautious in the subtle to prevent calamities,
but instead wait for calamities to form before applying remedies—
even the divine cannot act.

Trace calamities and misfortunes to their origins—
ten thousandfold the Dao’s methods,
yet no fixed remedy exists.

A tree thick enough to embrace grows from a hair’s end;
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
A ten-foot girth begins with a handful,
from a hair’s end it grows gradually,
small things accumulate into great.

A nine-tiered terrace rises from a clod of earth;
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
A hundred-zhang tower begins below,
layered earth becomes a mountain,
subtle things accumulate into vastness.

A thousand-li journey starts beneath one’s feet.
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
A lame tortoise travels a thousand li,
one halting step at a time,
near things accumulate into far.

Those who pursue ruin themselves—
*The Scripture of the Cavern Spirit* says:
Those who love white things
consider blackness filth.

Those who love wealth excessively
do not see other things worth loving;
those who love perversity excessively
do not see the Dao’s worth.

Men of the latter age who die young
are not without arts—
their cunning is extreme,
yet the more they scheme, the shorter their lives.
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Those who love affairs never fail to meet ruin,
those who love perversity never fail to lose.
Each pursues what they love
only to harm themselves—
thus it is said: *those who act bring ruin upon themselves.*

Those who grasp lose.
*The Scripture of the Cavern Spirit* says:
Those who love black things
consider whiteness filth.

Those who love horses excessively
do not see other things worth loving;
those who love ghosts excessively
do not see the divine’s worth.

In the latter age, those whose spirits grow wrathful
are not without reverence for the gods—
their licentious rites prevail,
and the gods grow ever angrier.

*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The reason men lose their states,
die in disgrace,
and become objects of scorn for all under heaven,
is never without their love of desires—
thus it is said: *those who grasp lose.*

Therefore, the Sage of old, as *The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says,
*"If the people of this age are perverse toward gods and spirits,
who can set them right?"*

Governance lies in the Dao, not in craft;
the gentleman cultivates upright qi,
the petty man cultivates perverse qi—
hence, the Sage acts without doing,
and so meets no ruin.
He does not grasp,
and so meets no loss.
Act without doing,
and so meet no ruin—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Those who delight in licentious rites,
heedless of future calamity,
are perverse qi—
thus it is said: *without doing, there is no ruin.*
Do not grasp,
and so meet no loss—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
In the latter age, those who cling to ghosts and gods,
heedless of future calamity,
are perverse qi—
thus it is said: *without grasping, there is no loss.*

The people’s undertakings
often falter just as they near completion.
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The origins of calamity and fortune are subtle and unseen;
the petty man does not know the gates of misfortune—
he stirs and falls into guilt,
unmindful of his subtle desires.
To be cautious at the end as at the beginning,
then there will be no ruined undertakings.
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious*—*Chapter of the Talisman*—says:
States fall from losing their governance,
filial piety wanes from lacking completion,
misfortune arises from grasping action,
illness stems from carelessness—
thus, to be cautious at the end as at the beginning,
there will be no ruined undertakings.

Therefore, the Sage, as *The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says,
*"The Sage perceives their beginning and end—
it cannot be neglected."*

Desire not what should not be desired.
*The Scripture of the Southern Flower*—*The Zhuangzi*—says:
Ancient men desired,
but desired what they could not desire—
their desire reached the Dao itself.
They did not prize hard-to-obtain wealth;
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Ancient men did not prize hard-to-obtain wealth,
nor value useless things.

Study not what should not be studied.
*The Scripture of the Southern Flower*—*The Zhuangzi*—says:
Ancient scholars studied,
but studied what they could not study—
their study reached the Dao itself.

Return to the faults of the common people.
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
In ancient times, toward virtue,
they did not slight the small and so failed to practice it;
toward faults,
they did not overlook the subtle and so failed to correct them.
To aid the natural unfolding of all things,
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Ancient Sages of old
were in nature aligned with the Dao—
they knew without study,
saw without looking,
heard without listening—
the natural Way itself.
Yet they did not dare to act.
*The Scripture of the Southern Flower*—*The Zhuangzi*—says:
In ancient times, above and below alike,
there was no doing.

*The Classic of the Dao and Virtue*—*Four Children’s Commentary on the Ancient Way*—Volume Eight concludes.
Volume Nine begins.

**Chapter Sixty-Five: Ancient Virtue in the Dao**

In the age of ancient great virtue and supreme Dao,
*The Southern Flower* speaks:
The Sage did not exalt the worthy,
nor employ the capable.
Above, like pruning branches,
the people were wild as deer.

Rectitude was natural—no need to call it *yi* (righteousness),
mutual love—no need to call it *ren* (benevolence),
sincerity—no need to call it *zhong* (loyalty),
truthfulness—no need to call it *xin* (faithfulness).
They moved clumsily yet guided one another—no need to call it a blessing.
Thus, they acted without leaving traces,
accomplished deeds without leaving records—
the people were simple and easy to govern.

Those ancient masters of the Dao—
*The Southern Flower* says:
The Sovereigns of the Mysterious Age
governed with *wuwei* (non-action),
merely embodying Heaven’s virtue.

Not to enlighten the people,
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Supreme loyalty restored simplicity—
the people harbored no deceit or concealment.
Rather, they sought to befuddle them.

*The Southern Flower* says:
In the southern lands, there was a village
named *Jiàn Dé* (Established Virtue),
its people simple and unrefined—
thus, they were easy to govern.

The difficulty in governing the people—
*The Southern Flower* says:
Now, the Zhou promote cleverness, skill, and ornamental culture—
insufficient to stabilize the realm.
The people are difficult to govern
because their intelligence is excessive.

*The Southern Flower* says:
If the ruler sincerely favors cleverness yet lacks the Dao,
the world falls into great disorder.
Thus, Jie and Zhou each brought chaos—
their crime lay in their love of cleverness.
Now, the people are difficult to govern
because their intelligence is excessive.

Thus, governing with cleverness is the ruin of the state.
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Those who govern with cleverness
rely on one man’s talent—
hard to sustain the state.
If they favor clever stratagems,
they breed deceit and corruption—
the winds that destroy nations.
Thus, governing with cleverness is the ruin of the state.
Not governing with cleverness is the state’s blessing.

*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious [Original Dao]* says:
Ancients did not govern with cleverness—
the state’s blessing.

To know these two truths—
*The Southern Flower* says:
Abandon petty cleverness, and great wisdom shines forth.
This is the model.

*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Those who govern with literary cleverness
labor in vain with weary hearts.
Relying solely on cleverness,
failures multiply.
To love cleverness is to exhaust artifice—
cleverness breeds calamity.
To counter cleverness with cleverness
is like stirring water to seek clarity—
difficult indeed.

Those who know the root of governance
abandon artifice and cleverness,
letting *wuwei* transform naturally.
Always hold to the model—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Now, if one seeks to learn the Dao
without attaining the pure, luminous, and sacred,
merely clinging to texts,
they cannot govern at all.
This is called *xuán dé* (Mysterious Virtue).

*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Ancient Sages held *xuán dé* in their hearts,
and their transformations moved like spirits.
Only those who harmonize with the Great Unity
and naturally respond can govern—
this is called *xuán dé*.
Mysterious Virtue is profound and vast—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious [Natural Dao]* says:
Ancient Sages preserved themselves with Heaven and Earth,
upright in cultivating the Dao.
The deeper the human path, the deeper the virtue;
the deeper the virtue, the more complete the achievements—
this is called *xuán dé*, profound and vast.
They inverted with things—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Their inversion with things was complete.

The Commentary says:
*"Long处* (prolonged) yet not *zhì* (wise/knowing), hence it is called *fǎn* (inversion).
Then it reaches *Dà Shùn* (Great Harmony).

*The Scripture of the South (Zhuangzi)* says:
When harmonizing with Heaven and Earth, their unity is seamless,
like the simplicity of the foolish and the dimness of the ignorant—
this is called *Mysterious Virtue*, in accord with *Great Harmony*.

**Chapter 66: The King of All Valleys (Jiānghǎi as King)**
This chapter of *The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* states:
In the ancient times, the Sage-Kings governed through the Dao/Way,
retiring yet without absence, modeling themselves after the rivers and seas—
not claiming greatness for themselves, their virtue naturally manifesting,
so they could establish their kingship.

Human nature and disposition
submit to virtue, not to force.
Virtue lies in yielding, not in contention—
thus the ancient Sage-Kings,
who wished to be honored by others, first honored others themselves;
who wished to be revered by others, first revered others;
who wished to overcome others, first made themselves weak;
who wished to be humble before others, first humbled themselves.

Thus high and low, reverence and humility,
the Dao/Way governs them—
speaking gently to others while placing themselves last,
so the world finds joy in promoting them without weariness,
and in bearing them without resentment—
this is virtue abundant and *qi* in harmony.

Thus knowing to yield is to take,
and to retreat is to lead—
this is near to the Dao/Way.

Virtue bestowed upon the world,
preserved through yielding,
was how the ancient Kings maintained the world—
thus they could endure long.
This is the virtue of the Sea yielding kingship.

**Why the rivers and seas can be kings of all valleys,**
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious [Natural Virtue/Compendium]* says:
The rivers and seas are low and humble,
yet all streams flow into them—
thus they achieve vastness.
Because they excel in yielding,
they can be kings of all valleys.

*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The rivers and seas yield because they are low,
the Heavenly Pool is the *Yuān Dé* (Abyssal Virtue),
and fish and turtles gather there.
Thus the sea does not contend with the eastward flow—
this is the utmost greatness.

Therefore, the Sage-Kings
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The rivers and seas occupy the Earth’s deficiencies,
so the world submits to and venerates them.
The Sage-Kings who practice humility, modesty, and yielding words—
this is seen as yielding.
Seen as yielding, thus they attain their loftiness;
the arrogant cannot stand.

*The Scripture of the South (Zhuangzi)* says:
Once upon a time, Yao and Shun yielded yet became emperors,
Tang and Wu contended yet became kings,
and the Duke of Bai contended yet perished.
To ascend over others, one must speak gently to them,
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious [Virtue/Compendium]* says:
To ascend over others,
one must necessarily speak gently to them.
The world must imitate their joy and love,
all must promote and yield.

To lead others, one must place oneself last,
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
To lead others,
one must necessarily place oneself last.
The world advances their benevolence and righteousness,
and there is no harsh *qi*.
Thus, though they occupy the highest position, others do not resent them,
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious [Dao/Way Origins]* says:
Thus, though they occupy the highest position, others do not resent them,
and though they stand foremost, others do not harm them—
the world submits to them, and the wicked fear them.
Though they stand foremost, others do not harm them.
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
To occupy the highest position while the people do not resent,
and to stand foremost while others do not harm—
even in distant lands and alien customs,
where maggots fly and worms writhe,
all are drawn to love them.
Thus the world finds joy in promoting them without weariness.
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Thus the world finds joy in promoting them without weariness,
without them, nothing is left undone,
without their leading, nothing fails to succeed—
hence they are held in highest esteem by the world.
Because they do not contend,
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious [Natural Virtue]* says:
The ancient skilled in ruling modeled themselves after the rivers and seas—
low and yielding, not contending.
All streams flow into them,
so none can contend with them.
Thus the Dao/Way does not stand upon strength and arms,
but upon the world’s promotion of them—
not upon their own seizing.
Because they do not contend,
none can contend with them.
Thus the world cannot contend with them.
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The Way of ordinary people is many and does not unite,
the Way of the Sage-Kings is humble yet none can surpass it.
Because they do not contend with all things,
the world cannot contend with them.

**The World All Praises (Chapter 67)**
This chapter of *The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* states:
The Dao/Way is simple yet expansive,
mysterious yet luminous,
soft yet strong—
containing yin and emitting yang,
and thus manifesting the three brilliances.

The sun and moon move through it,
mountains rise through it,
the abyss deepens through it,
birds fly through it,
beasts run through it,
the qilin roams through it,
and the phoenix soars through it.

To take reverence through humility,
to take survival through extinction,
to take precedence through retreat.

The first is *cí* (compassion),
the second is *jiǎn* (frugality),
the third is not daring to lead the world.

The ancient Sage-Kings preserved softness and did not grow rigid,
retired yet were not absent,
did not dare to be proud or extravagant—
their virtue naturally transformed,
so they could establish their kingship.
They could endure long,
and their three treasures were vast and expansive.

The world all praises my Dao/Way as great,
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
My Dao/Way is *wu wéi* (non-action),
and I do not privately receive what is unworthy.
It seems not to conform.
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
My virtue contains simplicity,
yet it tolerates the unworthy.
Only because it is great,
does it seem not to conform.
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The ancient skilled in ruling modeled themselves after the rivers and seas—
*wu wéi* (non-action), occupying unworthy positions,
so they became kings of the world.
If conformity were long sustained,
its subtlety would be lost.
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The ancient Sage-Kings were clear-sighted, wise, and benevolent,
yet they preserved themselves in simplicity,
practicing non-action while the world was governed.
I possess three treasures,
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
My Dao/Way has three treasures—
to take reverence through humility,
to take vastness through frugality,
to take precedence through retreat.
Preserving and holding them.
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The Dao/Way is preserved through them.

The first is compassion,
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The Dao/Way of Heaven and Earth,
great yet rooted in the small,
humble yet self-guarding.

The second is frugality,
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The Dao/Way of Heaven and Earth,
abundant yet beginning with the few,
frugal yet self-fortifying.

The third is not daring to lead the world,
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The Dao/Way of Heaven and Earth,
leading through retreat as its principle,
retiring to yield.

Thus, compassion brings forth courage—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The ancient sages followed the Dao’s humility,
so as to place themselves below others.
Humility yields honor—
this is the fulfillment of Heaven’s Way.

Frugality brings forth vastness—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The ancient sages followed the Dao’s frugality,
so as to begin with little.
Frugality yields abundance—
this is the fulfillment of Heaven’s Way.

Not daring to lead the world,
thus one attains the completion of great instruments and long reigns—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The ancient sages followed the Dao’s retreat,
so as to place themselves behind others.
Retreat yields precedence—
this is the fulfillment of Heaven’s Way.

Now, abandoning compassion and courage—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Men of the latter age love strength and hate weakness,
yet they do not know their loss—
the overbearing perish.

Abandoning frugality and vastness—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Men of the latter age love extravagance and hate frugality,
yet they do not know their loss—
the proud and wasteful perish.

Abandoning retreat and precedence—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Men of the latter age love to lead and hate to follow,
yet they do not know their loss—
those who contend for precedence are undone.
Death is near—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The root of reckless strength lies in humility and weakness;
the root of vast utility lies in frugality and restraint;
the root of striving for precedence lies in modesty and retreat.
When these three are lost, states perish and fall.

Compassion—
in war, it brings victory—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The Dao does not conquer through strength,
but through the world’s spontaneous submission,
not through self-assertion.
Softness and weakness prevail.

In defense, it makes firm—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
High walls and deep moats are insufficient for true defense.
The skillful guardian needs no walls.
Heaven will protect it—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Heaven’s Way diminishes the full and benefits the few.
*The Scripture of the Cavern Spirit* says:
When virtue and Dao flourish, spirits and gods assist—
this is the mark of the virtuous.

Compassion guards it—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
In times of order, righteousness guards the body;
in times of chaos, the body guards righteousness.

**Chapter Sixty-Eight: The Virtuous Warrior**
This chapter from *The South Flower Scripture* recounts:
Wei Wu Hou asked Xu Wu Gui:
*"I wish to love the people and practice righteousness while laying down arms—is this possible?"*
Xu Wu Gui replied:
*"Your armies stand like cranes at the ornate gate,
your formations do not rely on swift horses at the hallowed hall—
how can this be called laying down arms?
In ancient times, there was no storing of weapons for gain,
no outwitting others through cleverness,
no defeating others through schemes,
no conquering others through war.
Now, those who slaughter the people and seize their lands,
to nourish their own harmony and spirits—
who among them knows the art of war?
Where lies victory?
If you cannot cease, then cultivate sincerity within your breast,
responding to Heaven and Earth’s effortless nature without resistance.
When the people die, they are already freed—
what use is there in laying down arms?
The ancient virtuous warriors were not martial,
the skilled fighters did not rage.
Using the worthy without contention,
the world attains great peace.

The virtuous warrior is not martial—
*The Scripture of the Cavern Spirit* says:
Armor and weapons are insufficient for strength.

The skilled fighter does not rage—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The ancient masters of war stored their anger;
when anger was stored, their威 *wei* could be established.

The one who bests enemies does not contend—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The skilled warrior fights no one,
but rides the currents of time and follows the people’s desires—
and the world submits.

The master of men serves below—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The ancient masters of men were like the many feet of a centipede,
each aiding without harming,
or like the tongue and teeth—
firm and yielding, grinding without destruction.

Though the summer jade may have flaws,
and the moon’s pearl may bear blemishes,
yet the world treasures them—
the worthy do not let minor faults obscure great beauty.
To fixate on others’ shortcomings,
forgetting their virtues,
and yet seek the worthy in the world—
this is difficult indeed.

This is called the virtue of non-contention—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Those who win the hearts of men must first win themselves;
those who win themselves must be soft and weak.
Those who achieve hegemony and kingship must first be conquerors;
those who conquer must be virtuous.

This is called the power of using men—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
To love the worthy is benevolence;
to respect the worthy is ritual.

This is called aligning with Heaven—
the ancient ultimate.

*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
A thousand-chariot state practicing cultural virtue becomes king;
a ten-thousand-chariot state fond of war perishes.

**Chapter Sixty-Nine: The Five Kinds of War**
This chapter from *The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
There are five kinds of war:
There is the righteous war,
there is the responsive war,
there is the wrathful war,
there is the greedy war,
and there is the arrogant war.

To punish tyranny and rescue the weak—this is the righteous war.
When an enemy attacks and there is no alternative—this is the responsive war.
To quarrel over trifles, unable to master one’s own heart—this is the wrathful war.
To covet another’s land, to desire another’s wealth—this is the greedy war.
To boast of one’s state’s grandeur and people’s multitude,
and to seek superiority over enemy states—this is the arrogant war.

The righteous war brings kingship,
the responsive war brings victory,
the wrathful war brings defeat,
the greedy war brings death,
the arrogant war brings annihilation—
this is Heaven’s Way.

Now, the warring states’ rebellious ministers and traitors
use war lightly against enemies,
ambush the unprepared,
and first invite disaster—
no calamity is greater than underestimating the enemy.

There is a saying about war:
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious [Upper Section on Rites]* says:
To use the unusual in war,
the unusual becomes weary as if labored,
the unusual becomes hungry as if starved,
the unusual becomes restless as if disturbed,
the unusual becomes chaotic as if disordered,
the unusual becomes forward as if retreating.
Where does one go without victory?
The latter prevails.

I dare not act as master.

*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The one who strikes first is on the path to exhaustion.

Yet as a guest, *The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The one who moves last is the source of establishment.

I dare not advance even an inch,
but retreat a foot.

*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
To bend an inch to extend a foot—this is the way of the virtuous.

This is called "action without action,"
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Raising an army for others brings their aid;
raising an army for oneself brings their departure.

There is no arm to ward off,
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Where the multitude aids, though weak, it must grow strong.

There is no enemy to oppose,
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Where the multitude departs, though great, it must stand firm.

There is no weapon to grasp.
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The ancients held victory and triumph in not waging war while yet disbanding armies—when lords and vassals were in submission, this was the highest use of war.

No calamity is greater than underestimating the enemy,
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The bold and courageous die by their reckless strength;
the eloquent and clever are constrained by their own cleverness.
One who knows victory through cleverness is capable;
one who does not know defeat through cleverness is not.

Brave in one act, discerning in one word,
one may be persuaded by subtle arguments,
but not yet trusted to broad application.

Lightly underestimating the enemy almost loses one’s treasure.

The *Tongxuan Jing* says: A bow is drawn for shooting, yet without a string, it cannot release. Heaven’s shooting requires no bow—it strikes true.

The high are humbled,
The *Tongxuan Jing* [Guard Weakness Section] says: The Dao of Heaven humbles the high.
The low are raised;
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: The Dao of Heaven raises the low.
The excessive are diminished,
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: The Dao of Heaven diminishes the excessive.
The deficient are supplemented.
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: The Dao of Heaven supplements the deficient.

The Dao of Heaven diminishes the excessive and supplements the deficient,
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: The Dao of Heaven diminishes the excessive to nourish the deficient.
The Dao of Earth diminishes the high and benefits the low.
But the Dao of humanity is otherwise,
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: The Dao of the ruler is otherwise, differing from Heaven’s diminishing and benefiting.

It diminishes the deficient,
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: Yet the people, in their tilling, rely on their wives, children, aged, and weak for sustenance. Facing floods, droughts, and heavy taxes, they struggle to provide.
To nourish the excessive.
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: The ruler takes from the people to serve above, seeking only the surplus.

Who can use their surplus to nourish the world?
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: In the later ages, greedy tyrants drain their people to satisfy boundless desires, leaving the masses hungry and cold. Who can nourish the deficient?

Only the Dao-bearing ones.
The *Zhuangzi* says: The ancient sages took care of the old, weak, orphans, and widows, ensuring all were provided for.
Thus, the sages
The *Zhuangzi* says: The ancients were complete—they nurtured all things, and their benevolence extended to the people.

They act without claiming merit,
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: The Dao of Heaven and Earth—all things rely on it for existence, yet none know its virtue.
Their work accomplished, they take no credit,
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: The Dao of Heaven and Earth—all things complete their work without dwelling on it, yet none know its virtue.
They do not seek to be seen as virtuous.
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: The sage is empty of self, seeing only insufficiency. Seeing insufficiency, they achieve true virtue.

**Chapter 78: The Gentle and Weak of the World**
The *Tongxuan Jing* speaks: The sea does not reject the smallest streams to become great; the forests do not reject the crooked and bent to flourish. The sage does not reject humble words to broaden their name. If speech is true, even a common laborer’s words should not be discarded. If speech is false, even the ruler’s ministers should not be heeded. Right and wrong cannot be judged by rank or status.

When the people drown and the ruler does not grieve, he is not a virtuous sovereign. To guard one’s post and die in battle is the duty of a subject. In later ages, few ministers offer sincere loyalty, risking their lives. Those who exhaust their strength and loyalty go unheard.

Thus, the ancient sages modeled themselves after water’s gentleness—enduring shame, accepting criticism, and receiving insults. Rulers should emulate water in receiving defilement.

Nothing in the world is as gentle and weak as water,
The *Tongxuan Jing* [Dao Yuan Section] says: Nothing is as gentle and weak as water.
Yet it conquers the rigid and strong,
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: The Dao of water—it pierces metal and stone, its strength flows through the world.
And none can overcome it,
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: The Dao of water—its course cannot be exhausted, its subtlety cannot be grasped.
Nothing can replace it.
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: The Dao of water—struck, it leaves no wound; pierced, it suffers no harm; cut, it is not severed; burned, it is not scorched. It flows smoothly, never dispersing.

Thus, the gentle overcomes the rigid,
The *Tongxuan Jing* [Supreme Virtue Section] says: The *Laozi* saw the tongue and guarded gentleness. Though teeth are firmer than the tongue, they decay first.
The weak overcomes the strong.
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: Accumulated gentleness becomes rigidity; accumulated weakness becomes strength. Without accumulation, this cannot be.

The world
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: In the later ages, human nature favors strength and rejects weakness, rigidity and rejects gentleness, yet they do not know their loss and cannot embrace gentleness.

None know,
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: The virtuous discern truth and do not trust slander.
None can practice it.
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: If counsel is ignored, the ruler is unenlightened.

Thus, the sage
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: The ancient wise rulers modeled themselves after water’s gentleness.

Gentleness and frailty, though subtle and seemingly insignificant, thus attain their lofty heights—virtue and renown arise naturally. It says: *"To bear the filth of the state is to be called the sovereign of the ancestral altars;"* the *Tongxuan Jing* states: *"The ancient sages did not seek deeds that might be criticized, nor did they resent others’ censure of themselves. Though the world condemns them, they do not falter."*

*"To bear the state’s calamities is to be called the king of the world."* The *Tongxuan Jing* says: *"In ancient times, the sages allowed those who slandered them to do so, for it was their own fault."* Words once spoken cannot be recalled by others; actions begun nearby cannot be restrained from afar. Straight speech seems like perversion. The *Tongxuan Jing˙Upper Virtue Chapter* declares: *"In later ages, those who speak are silenced by words, those who advise are executed by law—yet such rulers still hope to preserve harmony across all lands. How far they are from wisdom!"*

**Chapter on Reconciling Great Grievances (79)**
This chapter of the *Tongxuan Jing* states: *"To reconcile great grievances will inevitably leave lingering resentment—how can this be called good?"* In ancient times, the near were drawn close not by words, the distant not by words; the near were made content, the distant were made to come. To share desires with the people brings harmony; to share their defenses brings stability; to share their thoughts brings understanding; to gain their strength brings wealth; to gain their praise brings renown. In the later ages, actions invite bandits, words invite disaster—no one speaks first, yet others have already conspired behind them. Rumors spreading a thousand miles are a calamity. The tongue is a trigger: once words are spoken, they cannot be recalled, even by four swift horses.

This exhorts the Warring States to reconcile their grievances, to cease hostilities and not contend, thus achieving universal peace—now that is good. To reconcile great grievances, the *Tongxuan Jing˙Subtle Brilliance Chapter* says: *"The ancient sages reconciled the world’s grievances, their virtue acting as the binding contract—non-contention was their goodness."* There must be lingering resentment—how can this be called good? The *Tongxuan Jing* says: *"The Warring States lacked the Dao; their conflicts bred resentment—there must be lingering resentment. How can this be called not good?"* Thus, the sage—

the *Zhuangzi* states: *"The ancient sages were fully prepared: to harmonize the world."* Holding the left contract, the *Tongxuan Jing* says: *"Yin harms things; yang transforms them."* The sage’s Dao follows the brilliance of yang to harmonize the world, follows the darkness of yin to reconcile its grievances and ill-will, yet holds no blame toward others. The *Tongxuan Jing* says: *"The greater the resentment, the deeper the calamity."* To harbor resentment without resolution is unheard of. Hence, virtue acts as the binding contract—the *Tongxuan Jing* says: *"Accumulated virtue becomes kingship; accumulated stone becomes mountains."* Without accumulation, this cannot be. Without virtue, there is no binding contract—the *Tongxuan Jing* says: *"Accumulated resentment brings ruin; accumulated water becomes rivers."* Without accumulation, this cannot be.

The Dao of Heaven favors none, always aiding the virtuous. The *Tongxuan Jing* says: *"The Dao of Heaven favors none, only virtue is rewarded."*

**Chapter on Small States and Few People (80)**
This chapter of the *Zhuangzi* (in the *Inner Chamber of the Chest* section) states: *"In the ancient age of supreme virtue, the clans of Róngchéng, Dàtíng, Bóhuáng, Zhōngyāng, Lìlù, Líxù, Hèxiū, Zūnlú, Zhùróng, Fúxī, Shénnóng, and Xuānyuán ruled. At that time, the people tied knots in cords for use, relished their food, adorned their dress, found comfort in their dwellings, and delighted in their customs. Neighboring states could see one another, and the sounds of roosters and dogs mingled in the air—yet the people lived until old age and death without visiting one another."* Such a time, when knots were tied in simplicity and the people were unadorned, universal peace meant supreme governance.

Small states, few people—the *Tongxuan Jing˙Symbolic Speech Chapter* says: *"To command ten thousand soldiers is not as good as to hear a single apt word; to possess the pearl of Duke Hòu is not as good as to grasp the proper means of governance; to hold the jade of Héshì is not as good as to align with the fitting course of affairs."* Though the world be vast, those who delight in war perish; though the state be stable, those who love contention are in peril. Thus, small states with few people, though they possess myriad implements, do not use them.

Though they possess myriad implements, they do not use them—the *Dònglíng Jing* says: *"The ancient sage-kings flourished by encouraging agriculture and teaching the people to till the land, to make death weighty and not wander far."* The *Tongxuan Jing* says: *"When Fúxī ruled the world, his virtue gave life without taking it."* At that time, there was no heart of profit or harm; the world was at peace. Though there were boats and carriages, there was no need to ride them—the *Zhuangzi* says: *"In the age of Shénnóng, when resting he slept soundly, when moving he walked leisurely, the people knew their mothers but not their fathers, and lived with deer and elk without malice. This was the peak of supreme virtue."*

Though there were armor and weapons, they were not displayed—the *Tongxuan Jing* says: *"Huángdì’s governance of the world refined the essence of sun and moon, regulated the qi of yin and yang, balanced the rhythms of the four seasons, established the laws of music and the calendar, distinguished male and female, clarified high and low. Farmers yielded the edges of their fields, and travelers did not pick up lost goods."* The people once again tied knots in cords for use—the *Zhuangzi* says: *"In the upper antiquity of supreme virtue, there was no action—yet the world was governed with ease, and both ruler and ruled were without strife."* The ruler did not act; the people did not act. They relished their food—the *Zhuangzi* says: *"The ancient people gathered acorns and chestnuts by day, and found their food sweet—thus they were called the people who knew life."* They adorned their dress—the *Zhuangzi* says: *"The ancient people did not know clothing, yet in summer they piled firewood, and in winter they burned it—thus their dress was beautiful, and they were called the people who knew life."*

The *Tongxuan Jing* says: In ancient times, their clothing was warm yet undecorated. They settled comfortably in their dwellings—
*The Nanhua Jing* says: The ancient people lived in nests and caves, resting in trees at dusk, finding comfort in their homes, thus they were called the people of the *Youchao Clan*.

The *Tongxuan Jing* says: In ancient times of great peace, neither soldiers nor horses crossed the borders of neighboring states, nor did armored chariot tracks extend beyond a thousand miles—all found comfort in their dwellings. They delighted in their customs—
*The Nanhua Jing* says: The ancient people delighted in their customs.
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: In ancient times, deceit did not arise; they lived in ease without strife, the world at harmony, their customs joyful.

Neighboring states lay in sight—
*The Nanhua Jing* says: In ancient times, neighboring states lay in sight, yet mountains had no paths or tunnels, marshes no bridges or ferries.
The sounds of roosters and dogs reached one another—
*The Nanhua Jing* says: In ancient times, the sounds of roosters and dogs reached one another, all creatures thrived in groups, bound to their lands.
The people lived until old age—
*The Nanhua Jing* says: In ancient times, the people lived until old age.
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: In ancient times, the strong did not oppress the weak, the many did not harm the few, so the people preserved their lives and did not die young.

They did not interact with one another—
*The Nanhua Jing* says: The ancient people lived alongside deer, hunted for food, and knew how to clothe themselves, with no intent to harm one another. They did not interact—this was the height of virtue.

*"True words are not ornate"*—Chapter Eighty-One of *Nanhua Zhenjing* speaks of the ancient Dao/Way and its techniques, which lay in *wuwei* (non-action). Laozi heard its teachings and rejoiced. He established it with the constant *wu* (non-being), governed it with *Taiyi* (Supreme Oneness), taking gentleness, humility, and yielding as its outward form, and emptiness, non-destruction of all things as its substance.

Laozi said: *"While others take what comes first, I take what comes last—thus I bear the world’s impurities. While others take what is solid, I take what is empty—thus I have no hoarding, and so I have abundance. While others seek fortune, I preserve myself—thus I avoid blame. I root myself in depth, bind myself with restraint, saying: ‘The rigid is destroyed, the sharp is blunted.’ In non-action, I laugh at cleverness, always yielding to things, never harming others—this is the utmost extreme."*

Laozi—truly the ancient sage of vast truth!

*"True words are not ornate,"*
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: In ancient times, the Great Dao was loyal yet simple, and the people had no deceit.
*"Ornate words are not true."*
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: Later generations knew contracts yet trust declined; they knew machinery yet substance declined. Minor cleverness breaks the Dao, harshness injures virtue.

*"The good do not argue,"*
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: In ancient times, the Dao was upright, non-action was not perilous, so the people easily followed.
The *Dongling Jing* says: Knowing without arguing is called the Dao; the Dao brings peace to the people.
*"Those who argue are not good."*
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: Later generations knew writing yet the Dao declined; minor arguments harmed the upright.
The *Dongling Jing* says: Knowing and then arguing is called discernment, used to govern people.
*The Nanhua Jing* says: Yet argument is never beneficial.

*"The wise are not all-knowing,"*
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: In ancient times of perfect governance, there was no labor, all were at ease, so the common people were not harmed.
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: Later generations knew calculations yet benevolence declined; minor achievements harmed governance.
*The Nanhua Jing* says: Yet knowledge without breadth is not wisdom.

*"The sage does not accumulate,"*
*The Nanhua Jing* says: The sage’s Dao flows without hoarding, thus all under heaven submitted.
Clear in Heaven, harmonious with the sage, with six penetrations and non-action, four openings in emptiness and stillness—those who embody the virtue of the sovereign—things act of themselves. In darkness, there is nothing that is not still.

*"To accumulate is insufficient; to hoard is to lack."*
The sage is cautious in what is accumulated.
Having given to others—
*The Nanhua Jing* says: Having given to others, the self becomes ever more abundant.
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: If kings and nobles uphold the Yang Dao, all things flourish; if they uphold the Yin Dao, the world perishes. If Yang does not descend to Yin, all things cannot form; if the ruler does not descend to the subject, virtue cannot spread.

*"The self becomes ever more abundant,"*
The *Chongxu Jing* says: Yao governed the world, wandering in broad streets, hearing children’s songs:
*"Establish our boiling people,
None but you are supreme."*
Not knowing, not knowing—
Following the Emperor’s way.
Having given to others...

*The Nanhua Jing* says: Having given to others, the self grows ever more abundant.

*The Tongxuan Jing* says: Kings and nobles dwell above the people, illuminating virtue and Dao. The noble withdraws from vice and embraces goodness, and the people do not stray far. Thus, the people have choices to depart or remain—when faults are severe, departures increase; when goodness prevails, those who stay grow ever more abundant.

*The Chongxu Jing* says: Yao rejoiced and asked the children, *"Who taught you to speak thus?"* The children replied, *"It is an ancient poem, and all the people sing with full bellies."* The Way of Heaven—

*The Nanhua Jing* says: The Heavenly Dao moves without accumulation, and thus all things flourish. It benefits without harming.

*The Tongxuan Jing* says: The sun rises from the earth, and all things thrive. When thunder moves, all things awaken; when rain nourishes, all things are refreshed.

The Sage’s Dao—

*The Nanhua Jing* says: The Imperial Dao moves without accumulation, and thus the world unites. The Sage’s mind is still, a mirror of Heaven and Earth, a reflection of all things. The world is at peace. Acting without contention.

*The Tongxuan Jing* says: The noble’s actions resemble the Dao. The movement of Yin and Yang follows fixed rhythms; the noble’s actions do not exhaust things. The wind does not stir without cause, fire does not flare without fuel. The noble does not speak, and the petty cannot fabricate. When fire emerges, it must await kindling; when the noble speaks, it must be true. With truth and sincerity, what cannot be accomplished?

*The Daoist Virtue and Power Classic: Four Masters’ Ancient Dao Exegesis* concludes here.

chunks.original_text: 道德真经四子古道集解 经名：道德真经四子古道集解。 金寇才质集。 十卷。 底本出处：《正统道藏》洞神部玉诀类。 参校本：无求备斋影印清蒋元庭刊道藏辑要本（简称清刊本）。 道德真经四子古道集解序 仆草泽无名之野人也，素不以进取介意。 及冠之后，酷嗜恬淡之乐，究丹经卜筮之术。 至於晚年，读古人书，披阅诸子，探赜聃经之奥，章章有旨，可谓深矣远矣。 因观诸家解注，言多放诞，互起异端，朱紫殽乱，殆越百家，失其古道本真，良可叹也。 独庄、列、文、庚四子之书，乃老氏门人亲授五千言教，各着撰义与相同。 其余诸解，纷纭肆辩，徒以笔舌为功，虚无为用，了无所执，又岂可与四子同日而语哉。 仆昔随仕尝游京都，得参高道。 讲师略扣玄关，尽为空性之说，不能述道之一二。 内省不疚，深其造道而自得，欲以拯世欲之多蔽，悼圣道之不行，又恐胶疑泥惑之流，翻起蜂喧之议，故摭其四子，引其真经，集为一编，计一十卷，以破雷同之说，因目之曰四子古道义。 又述经史疏十卷，以相为之表里。 今幸苟完是论，非当恃其臆说，不惟新当时闻见，抑为千古之龟鉴也。 请好事君子幸无哂焉，偃息之暇，因援笔而直书之。 时大定十九年己亥岁元日古襄寇才质谨序。 道德真经四子古道集解卷之一 古襄寇才质集 道可道章第一 此章《南华经》言：天地无为不言之教者，古之所大也，而三皇之所以共美也。 古之王天下者，奚为哉？ 天地无为而已矣。 古者大道不称，大辩不言，道昭而不道，言辩而不及。 后世孰知不言之教、不道之道？ 若有能知，此之谓天府大道无为，天地不言之大教矣。 天常无欲，无为自化，无教言也。 道可道， 《通玄经□道原篇》曰：夫仁义事生者，应变而动，变生於时，无常之行，故道可道，非常道也。 非常道。 《洞灵经》曰：后世仁义礼乐人事小成之道，曰可之教，饰辞政败，非常道也。 名可名， 《通玄经》曰：书学者，人言之所生也，言出於智，智者诈伪，不知於道。 夫着於竹帛之书，镂於金石之言，可传於人者，非藏书也，故名可名，非常名也。 非常名。 《洞灵真经》曰：后世多诵方书，或学技艺，通说之言曰可言之言，翦巧绮滥，非常言也。 无名，天地之始； 《通玄经》曰：无名则无形，大道无形即静而无为。 大常之道，不道之道，芒乎大哉，此之谓天府大道无教也。 有名，万物之母。 《通玄经》曰：有名则有形，天地有形即静而不言。 大常之言，不言之言，芒乎大哉，此之谓天府天地无言也。 常无欲，以观其妙， 《南华经》曰：有天道焉，无为而尊天道也。 天地大智，无为闲闲，大道无为，自然之妙也。 常有欲，以观其徼。 《南华经》曰：有人道焉，有为而卑人道也。 人学小智，有为闲闲，人道有为而徼幸也。 《通玄经》曰：有为也，则伤而徼末也。 此两者， 《通玄经》曰：循天者与道游也，随人者为俗学也。 《南华经》曰：天道之与人道也，相去远矣，不可不察也。 同出 《南华经》曰：合异以为同。 《通玄经》曰：圣人从事於教，同心而同归。 而异名， 《南华经》曰：散同以为异。 《通玄经》曰：后世五帝三王殊事而异路，五帝异道而覆天下，三王殊事因时而变而异言也。
chunks.translated_text:
**The Four Masters' Ancient Dao Commentary on the *Dao De Jing* (Preface)**

**Title:** *The Four Masters' Ancient Dao Commentary on the Dao De Jing*.
**Author:** Ke Houcai, a man of humble talent.
**Volume:** Ten.
**Source of the base text:** *Zhengtong Daozang* (正统道藏), *Tongshen Bu* (洞神部), *Yujue Leisure* (玉诀类).
**Collated edition:** *Wuqiu Beiqing* (无求备斋) shadow-printed *Daozang Jiyao* (道藏辑要) from Qing Jiang Yutang’s publication (hereafter referred to as the *Qingkan Ben* 清刊本).

---

**Preface to the Four Masters' Ancient Dao Commentary on the Dao De Jing**

I, your servant, am a nameless rustic from the marshes, one who has never sought advancement nor cared for worldly gain.
Upon reaching adulthood, I became deeply enamored with the pleasures of tranquility and simplicity, delving into the arts of *Dan Jing* (内丹经, Inner Alchemy) and divination.
In my later years, I read the works of ancient scholars, pored over the teachings of the *Zi* (诸子, Hundred Schools), and probed the profound mysteries of *Zhuangzi’s* (庄子) *Dao*, finding meaning in every passage—truly profound and far-reaching.

Observing the interpretations and annotations of other schools, I found their words often frivolous and extravagant, giving rise to conflicting doctrines, where red and purple (orthodox and heterodox) are indiscriminately mingled. Alas, they stray so far from the original Dao of antiquity, losing its true essence—how lamentable!

Only the works of the four masters—*Zhuangzi* (庄), *Liezi* (列), *Wenzi* (文), and *Gengzi* (庚)—are the true teachings of the *Five Thousand Words* (五千言), passed down directly by *Laozi’s* (老氏) disciples, each expounding upon the same Dao with consistent intent.
The other commentaries, though numerous and verbose, merely rely on ink and speech for their claims, offering no substance, no grounding in truth—how can they compare with the four masters?

In my youth, I once followed the court and wandered the capital, where I had the fortune to encounter the lofty Dao.
The lecturers there touched lightly upon the *玄关* (Xuan Guan, Mystic Pass), yet spoke only of emptiness and voidness, unable to convey even a fragment of the true Dao.
Reflecting inwardly, I felt no guilt, for my own understanding of the Dao was deep and self-attained.
I wished to rescue the multitude from their manifold obstructions, to mourn the Way’s failure to prevail, yet feared that those ensnared in doubt and confusion might rise in noisy contention.
Thus, I gathered the four masters’ works, cited the authentic *Jing* (经), and compiled them into one volume—ten in total—
to dismantle the redundant claims of others, and named it *The Four Masters' Ancient Dao Commentary*.

I also wrote *Ten Volumes of Commentary on the Classics and Histories* (述经史疏十卷) to serve as its counterpart.
Now, by fortune, this discourse is complete.
I do not presume to rely solely on my own conjectures,
but hope it may benefit both those of my own time and as a lesson for all ages.
May those of goodwill not scorn it,
and in moments of rest, take up their brushes and record it directly.

Composed on the first day of the Year of *Jǐhài* (己亥, 1915) in the *Dàdìng* (大定) era,
by **Ke Houcai** (古襄寇才质), with reverence.

---

**Volume One: The Four Masters' Ancient Dao Commentary**

**Chapter One: "The Dao That Can Be Spoken Of" (道可道)**

This chapter in the *Nanhua Jing* (南华经, *Zhuangzi*) states:
*"The silent, unspoken teachings of Heaven and Earth—without action—are what the ancients held in highest regard,
and what the Three Sovereigns (三皇) shared in common."*

What did the ancient rulers of the world do?
They simply followed *Heaven and Earth’s* (天地) Dao of non-action.

In antiquity, the *Great Dao* (大道) was not named, and great eloquence was not spoken of.
The *Great Dao* was manifest yet not proclaimed,
and words were eloquent yet did not reach their full extent.
Who in later ages understood the unspoken teaching and the unspeakable Dao?
If any could grasp it, then this is the *Heavenly Treasury’s* (天府) Great Dao of non-action,
and the silent, unspoken teachings of Heaven and Earth.

Heaven’s nature is without desire,
and non-action brings forth transformation naturally—
no teaching, no speech.
The Dao that can be spoken of—
*The Tongxuan Jing* (通玄经, *Dao Yuan* 道原篇) says:
*"The affairs of benevolence and righteousness arise from human contrivance,
responding to changes and moving with the times—
changes that come from the seasons, where nothing is constant.
Thus, the Dao that can be spoken of is not the constant Dao."*

Not the constant Dao—
*The Dongling Jing* (洞灵经) says:
*"The later ages’ Dao of benevolence, righteousness, ritual, music, and human affairs—
the so-called ‘teaching that can be spoken of’—
is merely an adornment of words and a failure of governance,
not the constant Dao."*

The name that can be named—
*The Tongxuan Jing* (通玄经) says:
*"The study of books arises from human speech,
which comes from wisdom—
yet wisdom is deceitful and false,
knowing nothing of the Dao.*
Those words inscribed on bamboo and silk,
or carved into metal and stone,
that can be passed down to others—
these are not the true treasures of the Dao.
Thus, the name that can be named is not the constant name."*

Not the constant name—
*The Dongling Zhenjing* (洞灵真经) says:
*"In later ages, many recite medical texts,
or study arts and crafts,
calling their spoken explanations ‘words that can be spoken of’—
mere clever embellishments, not the true words."*

Without name, there is the beginning of Heaven and Earth—
*The Tongxuan Jing* (通玄经) says:
*"Without name, there is no form,
and the Great Dao without form is stillness and non-action.*
The Dao of constancy, the unspeakable Dao—
vast and profound indeed!
This is the *Heavenly Treasury’s* (天府) Great Dao without teaching."*

With name, there is the mother of all things—
*The Tongxuan Jing* (通玄经) says:
*"With name, there is form,
and Heaven and Earth with form are stillness yet without speech.*
The constant speech, the unspeakable words—
vast and profound indeed!
This is the *Heavenly Treasury’s* (天府) Heaven and Earth without speech."*

Constantly without desire, one may observe its mysteries—
*The Nanhua Jing* (南华经) says:
*"There is the Dao of Heaven,
which is honored through non-action.*
Heaven and Earth possess great wisdom,
yet remain detached and effortless.
The Great Dao is non-action,
its mysteries unfolding naturally."*

Constantly with desire, one may observe its perils—
*The Nanhua Jing* (南华经) says:
*"There is the Dao of humanity,
which is humbled through action.*
Humans cultivate petty wisdom,
yet remain detached and effortful.
The Dao of humanity is action,
its perils born of contrivance.*
*The Tongxuan Jing* (通玄经) says:
*"Action leads to harm and peril—
this is the end of contrivance."*

These two Dao—
*The Tongxuan Jing* (通玄经) says:
*"Following Heaven is playing with the Dao,
while following humanity is mere worldly learning.*
*The Nanhua Jing* (南华经) says:
*"The Dao of Heaven and the Dao of humanity—
how distant they are!
One must not fail to discern them."*

**Shared Origin—**
*The Nanhua Jing* (南华经) says:
*"Unite differences to form the same."*
*The Tongxuan Jing* (通玄经) says:
*"The Sage engages in teaching,
uniting hearts and aligning paths."*

**Yet with Different Names—**
*The Nanhua Jing* (南华经) says:
*"Dissolve the same to form differences."*
*The Tongxuan Jing* (通玄经) says:
*"The Five Emperors and Three Kings of later ages pursued different affairs and divergent paths,
the Five Emperors differing in Dao yet bringing ruin to the world,
the Three Kings differing in affairs yet adapting to the times and changing their words."*

chunks.original_text: 同谓之玄。 《通玄经》曰：上古圣人与天同心，与道同体，谓之无为玄妙大道矣。 玄之又玄， 《南华经》曰：夫道深之又深，而能物焉； 神之又神，而能精焉。 众妙之门。 《通玄经》曰：道者一立而生万物，故万事之根皆出道之一门。 《南华经》曰：万物有乎生而莫见其根，有乎出而莫见其门。 其来无迹，其往无涯，无门无房，四达之皇皇也。 天下皆知章第二 此章《通玄经》言：圣人者，通於灵府，与造化者为人，执玄德於心，而化驰若神，无一言而大动天下，是以天心动化者也。 是故不言之教，芒乎大哉，不言之辩，不道之道，若或通焉，谓之天府大道无为，天地不言之教。 万物自化，不用小成，美有为言，民恶不善也。 天下 《通玄经》曰：后世无道治天下，天下之贼也。 有为也，则为天下用而不足治，上有为也，下亦有为也。 皆知美之为美， 《通玄经□微明篇》曰：后世知学浅於道矣，古不知学浅於道矣。 今之知学外於欲矣，古不知学内於性矣。 后世孰知知学为不知道，古不知学为知道乎？ 故天下皆知美之为美，斯恶矣。 斯恶矣； 《通玄经》曰：夫道不可以聪闻，聪闻非道，乃学也。 道不可以明见，明见非道，乃学也。 道不可以辩言，辩言非道，乃学也。 斯恶矣。 皆知善之为善， 《南华经□无始》曰：古不知学，深於道矣。 今知之学，浅於道矣。 弗知内性，知学外欲，於是泰清中而叹曰：古弗知学，乃知乎道，后世孰知不知之知乃知道乎？ 故天下皆知善之为善，斯不善矣。 斯不善矣。 《南华经》曰：夫道不可以聪闻，聪闻非道，乃学也。 道不可以明见，明见非道，乃学也。 道不可以辩言，辩言非道，乃学也。 斯不善矣。 故有无之相生， 《通玄经》曰：人君之道，有无相生也。 难易之相成， 《通玄经》曰：古者以正教化，易而必成。 后世以邪教化，难而必败。 舍其易必成，从事於难必败，故难易相成也。 长短之相形， 《通玄经》曰：古者民童蒙，长短不相形。 后世有为，长短之相形。 高下之相倾， 《通玄经》曰：古者民童蒙，高下不相倾，轻重均则衡，不倾无偏覆也。 后世高下之相倾。 音声之相和， 《南华经》曰：大人之教，若声之於响。 《通玄经》曰：如响之应声，上唱下和也。 前后之相随。 《南华经》曰：大人之教，若形之於影。 《通玄经》曰：如影之像形，前后相随也。 是以圣人 《通玄经》曰：大道之本在於法天，上圣法天。 法天者，法天地之道也。 虚静无为，是谓天地。 处无为之事， 《通玄经》曰：古王道者，处无为之事。 行不言之教。 《通玄经》曰：古王道者，行不言之教。 万物 《南华经》曰：今计物之为数不止於万而期日万物者，以数之多者，号而读之也，故曰万物。 作而不辞， 《南华经》曰：天不产而万物育，地不产而万物化。 生而不有， 《通玄经》曰：道生物也，莫见其所养而万物长，此之谓神明无为之道也。 为而不恃， 《通玄经》曰：道成物也，莫见其所为而万物成，此之谓神明无为之道也。 功成不居。 《通玄经》曰：不居者，无为也。 无为则不居，无名无言也。 大道无为，不知所为者而功自成。 夫唯不居， 《通玄经》曰：不居者，即处无为不动无言也。
chunks.translated_text:
**The Mysterious Unity**

*"The same is called the Mysterious."*

*The Tongxuan Jing* (通玄经) says:
*"The sages of antiquity harmonized their hearts with Heaven and their essence with the Dao—
this is called the profound, wondrous, and boundless Way of Non-Action."*

*"Mysterious beyond mysterious,"*
*The Nanhua Jing* (南华经) says:
*"The Dao is deep beyond depth,
yet it gives birth to all things;
Divine beyond divine,
yet it refines all things.
The gateway to all wonders."*

*The Tongxuan Jing* (通玄经) says:
*"The Dao stands alone yet gives rise to ten thousand things—
thus, the roots of all affairs emerge from the single gateway of the Dao."*

*The Nanhua Jing* (南华经) says:
*"All things arise yet no one sees their root;
they emerge yet no one sees their gateway.
Its coming leaves no trace,
its going knows no bound—
no gate, no door,
yet it moves freely in all directions.
The vast and boundless sovereign."*

---
**Chapter Two: The Unspoken Teaching of Heaven**

*The Tongxuan Jing* (通玄经) speaks:
*"The Sage penetrates the numinous treasury,
becomes human through alignment with Creation,
holds the Mysterious Virtue in heart,
and transforms with divine swiftness—
without a word, yet stirring the world.
Thus, the Sage moves Heaven’s heart and transforms it."*

Therefore, the teaching of the unsaid is vast beyond measure,
the argument of the unsaid is the Way that is not a Way—
if one attains it, it is called the boundless Dao of Heaven’s treasury,
the Non-Action of Heaven and Earth’s silent teaching.
All things transform spontaneously,
requiring no partial completion.
To speak of "beauty" is to mar it—
the people detest what is not good.

---
**The World**

*The Tongxuan Jing* (通玄经) says:
*"Later ages ruled without the Dao—
they were the world’s bandits.
Action, though useful, cannot govern.
When the ruler acts, the people also act.
All know beauty when it is called beauty—*
*The Tongxuan Jing* (通玄经, *□微明篇*) says:
*"Later ages knew learning was shallow compared to the Dao,
but the ancients did not know learning was shallow compared to the Dao.
Now, they know learning is external to desire,
but the ancients did not know learning was internal to nature.
Who in later ages knows that knowing learning is ignorance of the Dao?
Who knows that ignorance of learning is true knowledge of the Dao?
Thus, when all know beauty as beauty, it becomes evil.
It becomes evil."*

*The Tongxuan Jing* (通玄经) says:
*"The Dao cannot be heard with the ears—
hearing is not the Dao, but learning.
The Dao cannot be seen with the eyes—
seeing is not the Dao, but learning.
The Dao cannot be spoken with words—
speaking is not the Dao, but learning.
Thus, it becomes evil."*

*"All know goodness when it is called goodness—*
*The Nanhua Jing* (南华经, *□无始*) says:
*"The ancients did not know learning,
yet they were deep in the Dao.
Now, they know learning,
yet they are shallow in the Dao.
They do not know the inner nature,
but know learning as external desire—
thus, in the midst of purity, they sigh:
'The ancients did not know learning,
yet they knew the Dao.
Who in later ages knows that ignorance is true knowledge of the Dao?'
Thus, when all know goodness as goodness, it becomes ungoodness.
It becomes ungoodness."*

*The Nanhua Jing* (南华经) says:
*"The Dao cannot be heard with the ears—
hearing is not the Dao, but learning.
The Dao cannot be seen with the eyes—
seeing is not the Dao, but learning.
The Dao cannot be spoken with words—
speaking is not the Dao, but learning.
Thus, it becomes ungoodness."*

---
**The Interdependence of Opposites**

*"Being and non-being generate each other,"*
*The Tongxuan Jing* (通玄经) says:
*"The ruler’s Way lies in the interplay of being and non-being."*

*"Difficulty and ease complete each other,"*
*The Tongxuan Jing* (通玄经) says:
*"The ancients governed with upright teaching—
easy and it would surely succeed.
Later ages governed with perverse teaching—
difficult and it would surely fail.
To abandon what is easy and pursue what is difficult
is to court failure—
thus, difficulty and ease complete each other."*

*"Long and short define each other,"*
*The Tongxuan Jing* (通玄经) says:
*"In ancient times, the people were unspoiled,
and long and short did not contrast.
Later ages, with their actions, made long and short define each other."*

*"High and low incline toward each other,"*
*The Tongxuan Jing* (通玄经) says:
*"In ancient times, the people were unspoiled,
and high and low did not incline—
light and heavy balanced, untilted, without overturning.
Later ages saw high and low incline toward each other."*

*"Sounds harmonize with each other,"*
*The Nanhua Jing* (南华经) says:
*"The teaching of the Great Person is like sound to its echo."*
*The Tongxuan Jing* (通玄经) says:
*"Like an echo responding to sound,
the ruler sings above, the people respond below."*

*"Before and after follow each other,"*
*The Nanhua Jing* (南华经) says:
*"The teaching of the Great Person is like form to its shadow."*
*The Tongxuan Jing* (通玄经) says:
*"Like a shadow mirroring form,
before and after follow each other."*

---
**Thus, the Sage**

*The Tongxuan Jing* (通玄经) says:
*"The origin of the Great Dao lies in conforming to Heaven.
The highest sages conform to Heaven.
To conform to Heaven is to follow the Dao of Heaven and Earth—
emptiness, stillness, and Non-Action—
this is called Heaven and Earth.
To dwell in Non-Action,*
*The Tongxuan Jing* (通玄经) says:
*"The ancient kings of the Way dwelled in Non-Action.*
To practice the teaching of the unsaid,*
*The Tongxuan Jing* (通玄经) says:
*"The ancient kings of the Way practiced the teaching of the unsaid.*

*"All things*
*The Nanhua Jing* (南华经) says:
*"Now, when we count things by number, though they exceed ten thousand,
we call them 'ten thousand things' for the sake of naming and recitation—
thus, we say 'ten thousand things.'"*
*—are made yet not claimed,*
*The Nanhua Jing* (南华经) says:
*"Heaven does not give birth yet all things are nourished;
Earth does not give birth yet all things are transformed."*
*—born yet not possessed,*
*The Tongxuan Jing* (通玄经) says:
*"The Dao gives birth to things,
yet no one sees what nourishes them—
thus, all things grow.
This is called the divine and boundless Way of Non-Action."*
*—done yet not relied upon,*
*The Tongxuan Jing* (通玄经) says:
*"The Dao completes things,
yet no one sees what it does—
thus, all things are complete.
This is called the divine and boundless Way of Non-Action."*
*—and the deed accomplished without taking credit.*
*The Tongxuan Jing* (通玄经) says:
*"To not take credit is to practice Non-Action.
Non-Action means no dwelling, no speech, no action.
The Great Dao is Non-Action—
its deeds are accomplished without knowing what is done.
Only by not taking credit*
*The Tongxuan Jing* (通玄经) says:
*"To not take credit is to dwell in Non-Action,
to move without action, to speak without words."*

chunks.original_text: 是以不去。 《南华经》曰：道之无为而才自然矣。 至人之於德也，不修而物不能离焉。 不尚贤章第三 此章《南华经□天道篇》言：古者帝王之德，以天地为宗，以道德为主，以无为为常。 无为也，则用天下而有余。 是以太古圣人之治天下，虚心实腹，乃无为也。 常使民无知无欲不敢有为，不尚贤贵货。 无为则治也。 不尚贤， 《南华经》曰：上古大道至德之世，不尚贤，不使能，上如摽枝，民如野鹿。 使民不争， 《通玄经□下德篇》曰：后世人之情性皆愿贤己而疾不及人，愿贤即争心生，疾不及人则怨争生，怨争生则心乱而气逆。 古者圣王退争怨，争怨不生即心治而气顺？ 故曰不尚贤，使民不争。 不贵难得之货， 《通玄经□上义》曰：古者为国之道，其导民也，不贵难得之货，不重无用之物。 使民不为盗： 《南华经》曰：古者藏金於山，藏珠於渊，不利货财也。 不见可欲， 《通玄经》曰：古圣不见可欲，心与神静，乃无欲也。 使心不乱。 《通玄经》曰：后世人君好色，弗使风仪而国家昏乱，其积至於淫泱之难矣，故治人者慎所以感之。 《冲虚经》曰：后世君淫民淫，古圣淡然无欲而民自朴。 是以圣人之治， 《通玄经》曰：为治之本务在无为，是以圣人之治，虚无寂漠，修自然之道，淡然无为而天下治。 虚其心， 《通玄经》曰：其听治也，虚心得道。 圣人虚心无有者，见不足也。 见不足，故能成其贤，奢者不长。 实其腹， 《通玄经》曰：古者圣人守内而不失外，则胸腹充实而嗜欲寡也。 弱其志， 《通玄经》曰：其听治也，弱志得道。 志弱事强，安静不能不虑而得。 强其骨。 《通玄经》曰：古者至人之治也，弃其聪明，灭其文章，即合於神明无为之道。 神明得其内者，五藏宁，思虑平，筋骨劲强，耳目聪明，坚强而不匮，无所不逮。 常使民 《南华经》曰：古者无为也，则用天下而有余。 治上无为也，下亦无为也。 无知无欲， 《南华经》曰：古者同乎无知，其德不离。 同乎无欲，则民素朴。 使夫知者不敢为也。 《南华经》曰：上必无为而用天下，下必有为为天下用，此不易之道也。 为无为， 《通玄经》曰：为无为，事无事，知不知也。 《南华经》曰：帝王之务，在於无为。 则无不治矣。 《通玄经》曰：古者圣人淡然无为而无不为也，淡然无治而无不治也。 道冲章第四 此章《南华经》言：夫道冲和之气，和养万物也。 无所不在，是处有之。 在蝼蚁蠢物，无不养育，何其道下挫其锐邪？ 在瓦甓土石，无不成就，何其道愈甚散其纷邪？ 在稊稗草木，无不生成，其道愈下和其光耶？ 在屎溺粪壤，不拣秽污，同其尘也。 湛兮似或存，吾不知其大象乃谁氏之子，象帝之先天，象道气也。 道冲 《通玄经》曰：大道阴阳和气澄清。 而用之， 《通玄经□微明篇》曰：道冲而用之，又不满也。 或不盈。 《通玄经》曰：道者，和气冲而不盈。 渊兮似万物之宗。 《南华经》曰：天道冲和之气生成万物也，无所不在，是处有之。 挫其锐， 《通玄经》曰：夫道挫其锐者，无暴恶也。 解其纷， 《通玄经》曰：夫道解其纷，无争乱也。 和其光， 《通玄经》曰：夫道和其光者，无怨逆也。 同其尘， 《通玄经》曰：夫道和其尘，同尘秽也。
chunks.translated_text:
Thus, it is not abandoned. *The Nan Hua Jing* says:
*"The Dao’s Non-Action makes talent arise naturally.
The Perfect Man’s virtue—
unadorned, yet nothing can separate from it."*

**Chapter 3: Not Exalting the Virtuous and Wise**

This chapter of *The Nan Hua Jing* (□ *Tian Dao Pian*) speaks:
*"In ancient times, the virtue of emperors and kings took Heaven and Earth as their foundation, Dao and virtue as their master, and Non-Action as their constant. Non-Action means governing the world with abundance.
Thus, the sage-rulers of the most ancient times ruled the world with empty hearts and full bellies—this was Non-Action.
They always kept the people ignorant, desireless, and without daring to act, not exalting the virtuous, the wise, or wealth.
Non-Action brings governance.
Not exalting the virtuous—
*The Nan Hua Jing* says:
*'In the age of the Great Dao and supreme virtue, the virtuous were not exalted, the capable were not employed. The ruler was like a fallen branch, the people like wild deer. They made the people not contend.'
Making the people not contend—
*The Tongxuan Jing* (□ *Xia De Pian*) says:
*'In later generations, human nature and disposition all desire to surpass others and resent those who outdo them. Desiring to surpass breeds contention; resenting those who outdo breeds grievance and contention. Grievance and contention arise, then the heart is disordered and qi reverses.
The ancient sage-kings retreated from contention and grievance—when contention and grievance do not arise, the heart is governed and qi flows smoothly.'
Thus it is said: Not exalting the virtuous, making the people not contend.
Not valuing hard-to-obtain wealth—
*The Tongxuan Jing* (□ *Shang Yi*) says:
*'The ancient way of governing a state led the people, not valuing hard-to-obtain wealth, not prizing useless things, making the people not steal.
*The Nan Hua Jing* says:
*'The ancients hid gold in mountains, pearls in depths—they did not profit from wealth.'
Not seeing what is desirable—
*The Tongxuan Jing* says:
*'The ancient sages did not see what was desirable; their hearts and spirits were still, thus they were without desire, making the heart not disordered.
*The Tongxuan Jing* says:
*'In later generations, rulers indulged in beauty, not restraining their conduct, and the state fell into chaos, accumulating to the point of licentious calamity. Thus, those who govern must be cautious in what they inspire.
*The Chong Xu Jing* says:
*'Later rulers’ licentiousness led to the people’s licentiousness, but the ancient sages were serene and desireless, and the people naturally remained simple.'
Thus, the sage’s governance—
*The Tongxuan Jing* says:
*'The foundation of governance lies in Non-Action. Thus, the sage’s governance is empty, still, and tranquil, cultivating the Dao of Nature, serene and without action, yet the world is governed.
Empty the heart—
*The Tongxuan Jing* says:
*'In governing, an empty heart attains the Dao. The sage empties the heart of all things, seeing insufficiency.
Seeing insufficiency, thus able to perfect virtue, while the extravagant do not endure.
Fill the belly—
*The Tongxuan Jing* says:
*'The ancient sages guarded the inner while not losing the outer, thus their chests and bellies were full and their cravings few.
Weaken the will—
*The Tongxuan Jing* says:
*'In governing, a weakened will attains the Dao. A weak will and strong affairs—calm and undisturbed, yet naturally attaining.
Strengthen the bones—
*The Tongxuan Jing* says:
*'The governance of the Perfect Man abandoned cleverness, erased artifice, thus aligning with the divine and boundless Way of Non-Action.
When the divine attains the inner, the five viscera are tranquil, thoughts balanced, sinews and bones strong, ears and eyes keen—firm and unexhausted, nothing they cannot reach.
Always keeping the people—
*The Nan Hua Jing* says:
*'The ancients practiced Non-Action, thus governed the world with abundance. The ruler above practiced Non-Action, the people below also practiced Non-Action.
Ignorant and desireless—
*The Nan Hua Jing* says:
*'The ancients aligned with ignorance, their virtue not departing. Aligning with desirelessness, the people remained simple.
Making the knowing dare not act—
*The Nan Hua Jing* says:
*'The ruler above must practice Non-Action to govern the world; the people below must act to serve the world—this is the unchanging Dao.'
Practicing Non-Action—
*The Tongxuan Jing* says:
*'Practice Non-Action, manage without managing, know the unknown.'
*The Nan Hua Jing* says:
*'The emperor’s duty lies in Non-Action—then nothing is ungoverned.'
*The Tongxuan Jing* says:
*'The ancient sages were serene and without action, yet nothing was left undone. Serene and without governance, yet nothing was left ungoverned.'*

**Chapter 4: The Dao’s Effortless Flow**

This chapter of *The Nan Hua Jing* speaks:
*"The Dao’s effortless and harmonious qi nourishes all things.
It is everywhere, wherever it is, it exists.
In ants and crawling creatures, it does not fail to nourish and rear—why does the Dao humble itself to blunt their sharpness?
In tiles, bricks, soil, and stone, it does not fail to complete—why does the Dao, instead, further scatter their confusion?
In weeds and grasses, it does not fail to grow—does the Dao humble itself to soften its radiance?
In excrement, urine, and filth, it does not discriminate against filth—it equals them with dust.
Deep and vast, as if it might exist—
I do not know whose child this great form is;
it mirrors the Emperor’s primordial Heaven, the Dao’s qi.
The Dao’s effortless flow—
*The Tongxuan Jing* says:
*'The Great Dao’s yin-yang harmonious qi is pure and clear.
And its use—
*The Tongxuan Jing* (□ *Wei Ming Pian*) says:
*'The Dao’s effortless flow is used, yet it is not full.
Sometimes it does not overflow.
*The Tongxuan Jing* says:
*'The Dao—harmonious qi, effortless yet not full.
Deep, as if the origin of all things.
Blunting their sharpness—
*The Tongxuan Jing* says:
*'The Dao blunts sharpness—there is no cruelty or evil.
Dissolving their confusion—
*The Tongxuan Jing* says:
*'The Dao dissolves confusion—there is no contention or disorder.
Softening its radiance—
*The Tongxuan Jing* says:
*'The Dao softens its radiance—there is no grievance or resistance.
Equaling the dust—
*The Tongxuan Jing* says:
*'The Dao equals the dust—it unifies with filth.'"

chunks.original_text: 湛兮似或存。 《通玄经》曰：天以之清，湛然澄静。 吾不知谁之子， 《南华经》曰：吾不知其谁氏之子。 象帝之先。 《南华经》曰：冉求问於仲尼曰：未有形道之子孙而以有形天地子孙，可乎？ 仲尼曰：可有形先天地生者，皆物邪？ 物於物者，道非物物。 天地章第五 此章《南华经知北游篇》言：天地有大美而不言，四时有明法而不议，万物有成理而不说。 古圣人者，原天地无为之美，达万物自然之理，是故圣人无为，大圣不作，观於天地无为之谓也。 不教仁义小成、有为多言之事，以百姓为草狗，随圣人之风声自然偃化，天下治也。 天地不仁， 《通玄经□自然篇》曰：天地之道，以德为主，道为之命，物以自正。 至微其内，不以事贵，不须礼而庄，故道立而不教，明照而不察。 道立而不教者，不夺人能也。 明照而不察者，不害其事也。 夫教道者，逆於德害於物，故阴阳四时五行同道而异理，万物同情而异形，智者不相教，能者不相受，故天地不仁，以万物为刍狗。 以万物为刍狗； 《通玄经》曰：天地非有为焉，正其道而物自然。 阴阳四时非生万物也，雨露时降非养草木也，神明接，阴阳和，万物生矣。 圣人不仁， 《通玄经》曰：圣人立法以导民之心，各使自然，故生者无德，死者无怨。 夫慈爱仁义者，近狭之道也。 狭者入大而迷，近者行远而惑。 圣人入大不迷，行远不惑，常虚自守，可以为极，是谓天德。 故圣人不仁，以百姓为刍狗。 以百姓为刍狗。 《通玄经》曰：百姓听上如草从风，其於化也若风之靡草。 天地之间， 《南华经》曰：地籁则众窍是也。 夫籁者，大块噫气，其名为风，吹万不同，而使其自然也。 咸其自取，万物怒号者，其谁使耶？ 其犹弃钥乎？ 《南华经》曰：人籁则比竹是已。 风唯无作，作则万物鸣号，动而为声也。 冷风则小和，飘风则大和，犹吹人籁比竹管钥之声乎。 虚而不屈， 《通玄经》曰：上圣法天虚静无为，治天地之道也。 知虚静之道，乃能终始，是谓天地也。 动而愈出。 《冲虚经》曰：唐之治天下，游於康衢，闻儿童谣曰：立我蒸民，莫匪尔极。 不识不知，顺帝之则。 唐喜问曰：谁教尔为此谣言乎？ 童儿曰：古诗也。 多言数穷， 《通玄经》曰：后世民知书而道衰，知数而德衰，任数者劳而无功，书数者人言之所生也。 言出於智，智者诈伪，不知於道。 多言数穷，不如守中。 《冲虚经》曰：齐鲁多机巧，有善书数者。 不如守中。 《通玄经》曰：为教之本在去小成。 体道者，佚而不穷，神化无为，天下相应微矣，此所谓天地不言之教，芒乎大哉。 后世若有能知，此之谓天府大道无为，天地不言之教矣。 谷神章第六 此章《南华经》言：大道无形，有情鬼神帝，生天生地。 天得一气，清虚主其运也，地得一气，安宁处其甩也。 故天地谷神不死，是谓阴阳玄牝造化之神。 玄牝，阴阳之门户，是运天地根。 天则绵绵若存，地则用之不勤。 道，天地之根也。 谷神不死， 《冲虚经》曰：天地常生常化者，无时不生，无时不化，四时尔，谷神不死。 是谓玄牝。 《冲虚经》曰：大道常生常化，无物不生，无物不化，阴阳尔，是谓玄牝。 玄牝之门， 《冲虚经》曰：大道阴阳，疑独其道不可穷玄牝之门。
chunks.translated_text:
The Dao abides as if it exists.
*The Tongxuan Jing* says:
*"Heaven, through it, is clear—
serene and still."*

I do not know whose child it is.
*The Nanhua Jing* says:
*"I do not know whose child it is."*

It precedes the Emperor.
*The Nanhua Jing* says:
*"Ran Qiu asked Zhongni:
'Can the child of the formless Dao
be the ancestor of the formed Heaven and Earth?'
Zhongni said:
'If there is something that precedes Heaven and Earth in form,
is it not all things?
Things arise from things—
the Dao is not the maker of things.'*

**Chapter Five: Heaven and Earth**
This chapter of *The Nanhua Jing (Zhi Beiyou)* speaks:
*"Heaven and Earth possess great beauty yet do not speak,
the four seasons have clear laws yet do not debate,
all things have their natural order yet are not explained.
Ancient sages observed Heaven and Earth’s effortless beauty,
grasped the natural principles of all things—
thus the sage does nothing,
the great sage takes no action,
observing Heaven and Earth’s effortless Way.
They do not teach the petty virtues of benevolence and righteousness,
nor the many words of artificial deeds,
treating the people as grass-dogs,
following the natural winds of the sage—
thus the world is governed."*

Heaven and Earth are not benevolent.
*The Tongxuan Jing (Natural Section)* says:
*"The Way of Heaven and Earth takes virtue as its master,
the Dao as its decree,
things self-regulate.
Most subtle within,
it does not honor rank through deeds,
nor demand ritual to be solemn—
thus the Dao stands without teaching,
its radiance shines without scrutiny.
The Dao stands without teaching—
it does not deprive people of their abilities.
Its radiance shines without scrutiny—
it does not harm their affairs.
Those who teach the Dao
act against virtue and harm things—
thus yin-yang, the four seasons, and the Five Phases
share the Dao yet differ in principle,
all things share sentiment yet differ in form.
The wise do not instruct one another,
the capable do not receive from one another—
thus Heaven and Earth are not benevolent,
treating all things as grass-dogs."*

Treating all things as grass-dogs.
*The Tongxuan Jing* says:
*"Heaven and Earth do not act artificially—
they rectify the Dao, and things naturally arise.
Yin-yang and the four seasons do not create all things,
timely rain and dew do not nourish plants—
when divine resonance meets,
yin-yang harmonizes,
all things are born."*

The sage is not benevolent.
*The Tongxuan Jing* says:
*"The sage establishes laws to guide the people’s hearts,
letting them follow their nature—
thus the living have no virtue,
the dead have no grievance.
Benevolence, love, righteousness—
these are narrow ways.
The narrow enter the great and are lost,
the near travel far and are confused.
The sage enters the great without losing his way,
travels far without confusion,
constantly empty and self-guarded—
this is called Heaven’s virtue.
Thus the sage is not benevolent,
treating the people as grass-dogs."*

Treating the people as grass-dogs.
*The Tongxuan Jing* says:
*"The people follow their ruler like grass follows the wind,
their transformation is like wind swaying grass."*

Between Heaven and Earth,
*The Nanhua Jing* says:
*"Earthly resonance—this is the multitude of holes.
Resonance—
the Great Block exhales, its name is Wind,
blowing in myriad ways,
yet letting things be natural.
All things roar and cry—
who commands them?
It is as if they cast away their keys."*

*The Nanhua Jing* says:
*"Human resonance—this is the bamboo pipes.
Wind acts without force—
if it acts, all things roar and cry,
movement becomes sound.
A cool wind brings small harmony,
a gusting wind brings great harmony—
like blowing through human resonance,
bamboo pipes, or keys."*

Empty yet unyielding,
*The Tongxuan Jing* says:
*"The highest sage follows Heaven’s empty stillness and effortless action—
this is the Way to govern Heaven and Earth.
Knowing the Way of empty stillness,
one can begin and end—
this is called Heaven and Earth."*

Moving yet ever emerging.
*The Chongxu Jing* says:
*"The Tang ruled the world,
wandering the broad streets,
heard children’s songs:
*'Establish the boiling people,
none but your extreme.'*
Not knowing, not knowing,
following the Emperor’s decree.
Tang asked joyfully:
'Who taught you this song?'
The child said:
'An ancient poem.'*

Many words lead to exhaustion.
*The Tongxuan Jing* says:
*"Later generations know books yet the Dao declines,
know numbers yet virtue declines.
Those who rely on numbers labor without fruit,
those who rely on books and numbers
are born from clever speech.
Words arise from intelligence—
the clever are deceitful and false,
unaware of the Dao.
Many words lead to exhaustion—
better to guard the Middle."*

*The Chongxu Jing* says:
*"Qi and Lu abound in clever devices,
there are those skilled in books and numbers."*

Better to guard the Middle.
*The Tongxuan Jing* says:
*"The foundation of teaching lies in removing petty achievements.
Those who embody the Dao
are at ease and unexhausted,
their spirit transforms effortlessly—
the world subtly responds.
This is called Heaven and Earth’s unspeakable teaching—
vast and boundless!
If later ages know this,
it is called the great Dao of Heaven’s treasury,
Heaven and Earth’s unspeakable teaching."*

**Chapter Six: The Valley Spirit**
This chapter of *The Nanhua Jing* speaks:
*"The Great Dao is formless,
yet it gives birth to emotions, ghosts, gods, and the Emperor—
it generates Heaven and Earth.
Heaven receives one breath—
clear and empty, it governs its movement,
Earth receives one breath—
settled and tranquil, it holds its place.
Thus the Valley Spirit of Heaven and Earth does not die—
this is called the divine mystery of yin-yang’s primal mother,
the creative force.
The primal mother—
the gateway of yin-yang,
the root that moves Heaven and Earth.
Heaven is continuous, as if it exists,
Earth uses it without effort.
The Dao—
the root of Heaven and Earth.
The Valley Spirit does not die,
*The Chongxu Jing* says:
*'Heaven and Earth constantly generate and transform—
never ceasing to generate,
never ceasing to transform,
the four seasons—
the Valley Spirit does not die.'
This is called the primal mother.
*The Chongxu Jing* says:
*'The Great Dao constantly generates and transforms,
nothing it does not generate,
nothing it does not transform—
yin-yang—
this is called the primal mother.
The gateway of the primal mother,
*The Chongxu Jing* says:
*'The Great Dao’s yin-yang—
doubtful, its Way is unfathomable,
the gateway of the primal mother.'"
