chunks.original_text: 有虞氏有为，其犹减善仁义以要求人心为善，亦得人心诈伪，而未始仁心出於非人。 古者圣人能为无为之道，无事无味不为难也。 为无为， 《通玄经》曰：为无为，事无事也。 《南华经》曰：逍遥无为也。 事无事， 《通玄经》曰：事无事，知不知也。 《南华经》曰：逍遥乎无事之业。 味无味。 《通玄经》曰：古之人味道不舍也，今之人舍道不味也。 大小 《通玄经》曰：天地之道，大以小为本，道大以小为成。 古圣人法天无为，柔弱微妙者，见小也。 见小，故能成其大。 多少， 《通玄经》曰：天地之道，多以少为主，道多以少而成。 古圣人法天无为，以道莅天下，损缺其明者，见少也。 见少，故能成其美。 报怨以德。 《通玄经》曰：其施厚者其报美，其怨大者其患深。 薄施而厚望，畜怨而无患者，未之有也。 察其所以往，则知其所以来矣。 图难於其易， 《通玄经》曰：古者以正教化，易而必成，后世以邪教化，难而必败。 为大於其细。 《通玄经》曰：事或易为而难成者，或难成而易败者。 易为而难成者，事也。 难成而易败者，言也。 天下难事必作於易， 《通玄经》曰：人皆知无用害有用，故智不博。 而日不足难成其道矣。 天下大事必作於细。 《通玄经》曰：以博奕之日问道，闻见深矣。 易而不难，小而不大。 是以圣人 《通玄经》曰：不言而信，不施而仁，不行而治，不为而成，是以天心动化精诚为教者，三皇无为也。 终不为大，故能成其大。 《通玄经》曰：古之善为君者，法於江海。 江海无为，无不为大，百川归之，故能成其大。 夫轻诺必寡信， 《通玄经》曰：言而不信，施而不仁，行而不治，为而不成，是以外貌有为者，五帝三王不精诚於道也。 多易必多难。 《通玄经》曰：后世无政教之原，而欲为万人之上也，难矣。 是以圣人 《通玄经》曰：事者难成易败，言者难立易废，是以圣人之所留心於道，明者之所独见於无为也。 犹难之，故终无难。 《通玄经》曰：舍其易而必成，从事於难必败，愚惑之所政。 上无为也，下亦无为。 其安易持章第六十四 此章《通玄经》言：末世之人邪欲失性，动未尝正也。 以治国则乱，以治身则伪。 不闻道者无以反正，不通德者不能清静。 原人之性无邪秽，久好於邪，则易易而忘其本，即好於邪。 水之性欲清，沙土秽之，人之性欲正，邪言害之。 知其己奸无所用，虽贪者皆辞之，不知其己欲无所用，虽廉者不能让之。 夫人之所以亡社稷，身死人手，以为天下笑者，未尝非己所好也，故为者败之，执者失之。 知冬日之扇、夏日之裘无用於己，万物变为尘垢，无所用矣。 故曰：无为故无败，无执故无失。 其安易持， 《通玄经》曰：智虑邪正者，祸福之门也。 其未兆易谋， 《通玄经》曰：动静公私者，利害之枢机也。 其脆易破， 《通玄经》曰：夫祸之至也，人自生之； 福之来也，人自成之。 其微易散。 《通玄经》曰：积正成福，积邪成祸。 为之於未有， 《通玄经》曰：凡人皆轻小害，易微事，以至於大患至，不可不慎也。 后人皆知祸发救患，不知慎微使患不生。 夫使患不生易，施於救患难。 治之於未乱。 《通玄经》曰：道者慎小微，大祸不滋。 今人不务慎微使患不生，而务祸成施救於患，虽神人不能为。
chunks.translated_text:
The House of You had action,
yet it still relied on reducing benevolence and righteousness to coerce the people’s hearts toward goodness—
yet it still gained the people’s deceit and falsehood,
and never truly cultivated a benevolent heart beyond humanity.

The ancient sages could practice the Dao/Way of non-action,
for non-action was not difficult—
non-action, *The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Non-action is non-action—
*The South华经* says:
Adrift in non-action.

Non-action in affairs is non-action—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Non-action in affairs is knowing the unknown—
*The South华经* says:
Adrift in the business of non-affairs.

Non-action in taste is non-taste—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The ancients savored the Dao without abandoning it,
while modern men abandon the Dao without savoring it.

Great and small—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The Dao of Heaven and Earth,
greatness rooted in the small,
the Dao great in its completion through the small.
The ancient sages modeled Heaven’s non-action,
softness, weakness, subtlety, and mystery—
this was seeing the small.
Seeing the small, thus they could achieve the great.

Much and little—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The Dao of Heaven and Earth,
abundance rooted in scarcity,
the Dao abundant in its completion through the little.
The ancient sages modeled Heaven’s non-action,
governing the world with the Dao,
diminishing their brilliance—
this was seeing the little.
Seeing the little, thus they could achieve the beautiful.

Repaying resentment with virtue/power—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The thicker the giving, the finer the return,
the greater the resentment, the deeper the calamity.
Sparse giving with great expectations,
nurturing resentment without calamity—
this has never existed.

Observe how they proceed,
and you shall know how they arrived.

Planning difficulties in their ease—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The ancients used upright teachings,
easy and thus certain to succeed,
while later generations used perverse teachings,
difficult and thus certain to fail.

Doing greatness in their minutiae—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Some things are easy to do but difficult to complete,
others difficult to complete but easy to ruin.
Easy to do but difficult to complete—these are affairs.
Difficult to complete but easy to ruin—these are words.

The world’s difficult matters must begin in ease—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Men all know to discard the useless for the useful,
yet their daily lives are insufficient to complete the Dao.

The world’s great matters must begin in the small—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
On days of gambling and games, they inquire about the Dao,
yet their hearing and seeing are profound.

Easy yet not difficult,
small yet not great—
Thus the sages—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
They speak without being believed,
act without benevolence,
govern without order,
achieve without doing—
thus the heart of Heaven moves with sincere teaching,
the Three Sovereigns practiced non-action.
They never sought greatness,
and thus achieved the great.

*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The ancient wise rulers modeled the rivers and seas.
The rivers and seas practice non-action,
yet nothing is beyond their greatness—
all streams flow to them,
thus they achieve the great.

Light promises must be few in truth—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Speaking without truth,
acting without benevolence,
governing without order,
doing without achievement—
thus the superficial pretenders,
the Five Emperors and Three Kings did not sincerely adhere to the Dao.

Many easinesses bring many difficulties—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Later generations, lacking the roots of governance and teaching,
yet desiring to rule over the myriad people—
this is difficult.

Thus the sages—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Affairs are difficult to complete but easy to ruin,
words are difficult to establish but easy to abandon—
thus the sages focused their hearts on the Dao,
the enlightened saw uniquely in non-action.

Yet difficulties remain,
and thus they are ultimately without difficulty.

*Chapter Sixty-Four on Ease in Holding Firm*

*This chapter of The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* speaks:
The people of the end times indulge in perverse desires and lose their nature—
their movements are never upright.
Governance brings chaos,
self-cultivation brings falsehood.
Those who do not hear the Dao cannot return to rectitude,
those who do not understand virtue/power cannot achieve tranquility.

Human nature is originally without perversity,
yet prolonged indulgence in perversity
makes the easy seem easy and forgets its root—
thus they cling to perversity.
Water’s nature desires clarity,
yet sand and soil defile it;
human nature desires rectitude,
yet perverse speech harms it.

Knowing their own deceit is useless,
even the greedy will reject it,
yet not knowing their own desires are useless,
even the virtuous cannot relinquish them.

Thus men lose their states and die by others’ hands,
becoming the world’s laughter—
they have never failed to indulge their own desires,
thus those who act bring ruin,
those who grasp lose.

Knowing winter fans and summer furs are useless to them,
all things turn to dust and filth—
useless.

Thus it is said:
Non-action, hence no ruin,
non-grasping, hence no loss.

Its ease is easy to hold—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Wisdom discerning right and wrong
is the gateway to calamity and fortune.

Its unmanifested is easy to plan—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Movement and stillness, public and private—
the pivot of gain and harm.

Its fragile is easy to break—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Calamity’s arrival—
men themselves generate it;
fortune’s coming—
men themselves complete it.

Its subtle is easy to disperse—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Accumulating rectitude brings fortune,
accumulating perversity brings calamity.

Doing it before it arises—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Men all neglect minor harms,
easy trivial matters,
until great calamities arrive—
one must be cautious.

Later men know to respond to calamities after they arise,
yet do not know to be cautious in the subtle to prevent calamities from forming.
Preventing calamities from arising is easy,
yet applying remedies after calamities form is difficult.

Curing it before chaos—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The Dao is cautious in the small and subtle,
great calamities do not flourish.
Yet modern men do not strive to be cautious in the subtle to prevent calamities,
but instead wait for calamities to form before applying remedies—
even the divine cannot act.

Trace calamities and misfortunes to their origins—
ten thousandfold the Dao’s methods,
yet no fixed remedy exists.

A tree thick enough to embrace grows from a hair’s end;
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
A ten-foot girth begins with a handful,
from a hair’s end it grows gradually,
small things accumulate into great.

A nine-tiered terrace rises from a clod of earth;
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
A hundred-zhang tower begins below,
layered earth becomes a mountain,
subtle things accumulate into vastness.

A thousand-li journey starts beneath one’s feet.
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
A lame tortoise travels a thousand li,
one halting step at a time,
near things accumulate into far.

Those who pursue ruin themselves—
*The Scripture of the Cavern Spirit* says:
Those who love white things
consider blackness filth.

Those who love wealth excessively
do not see other things worth loving;
those who love perversity excessively
do not see the Dao’s worth.

Men of the latter age who die young
are not without arts—
their cunning is extreme,
yet the more they scheme, the shorter their lives.
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Those who love affairs never fail to meet ruin,
those who love perversity never fail to lose.
Each pursues what they love
only to harm themselves—
thus it is said: *those who act bring ruin upon themselves.*

Those who grasp lose.
*The Scripture of the Cavern Spirit* says:
Those who love black things
consider whiteness filth.

Those who love horses excessively
do not see other things worth loving;
those who love ghosts excessively
do not see the divine’s worth.

chunks.original_text: 末世神怒者，非不祀神也，淫祀胜，神愈怒。 《通玄经》曰：夫人之所以亡社稷，身死人怨，为天下笑，未尝非好欲也，故曰执者失之。 是以圣人 《通玄经》曰：今天下之人邪於神鬼，孰能正之？ 治在道不在术，君子行正气，小人行邪气，是以圣人无为故无败； 无执故无失。 无为，故无败， 《通玄经》曰：好於淫祀，不顾后祸者，邪气也，故曰无为故无败。 无执，故无失。 《通玄经》曰：末世执於鬼神，不顾后患者，邪气也，故曰无执故无失。 民之从事，常於几成而败之。 《通玄经》曰：祸福之起微而不可见，小人不知祸患之门，动而陷於罪，不慎微好也。 慎终如始，则无败事。 《通玄经□符言篇》曰：官败於失政，孝衰於无终，患生於执为，病在於不慎，故慎终如始，无败事也。 是以圣人 《通玄经》曰：圣人见其终始，不可不察也。 纣为象着而箕子唏其华侈，鲁以偶人葬而孔子叹其非礼。 见其所始，则知其所终。 欲不欲， 《南华经》曰：古人欲者，欲其所不能欲也，至欲於道矣。 不贵难得之货； 《通玄经》曰：古人不贵难得之货，不重无用之物。 学不学， 《南华经》曰：古之学者，学其所不能学也，至学於道矣。 复众人之所过。 《通玄经》曰：古人之於善也，无小而不行； 其於过也，无微而不改。 以辅万物之自然， 《通玄经》曰：古之圣人者，性合乎道也，不学而知，不视而见，不听而聪，自然之道也。 而不敢为。 《南华经》曰：古者上无为也，下亦无为也。 道德真经四子古道集解卷之八竟 道德真经四子古道集解卷之九
chunks.translated_text:
In the latter age, those whose spirits grow wrathful
are not without reverence for the gods—
their licentious rites prevail,
and the gods grow ever angrier.

*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The reason men lose their states,
die in disgrace,
and become objects of scorn for all under heaven,
is never without their love of desires—
thus it is said: *those who grasp lose.*

Therefore, the Sage of old, as *The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says,
*"If the people of this age are perverse toward gods and spirits,
who can set them right?"*

Governance lies in the Dao, not in craft;
the gentleman cultivates upright qi,
the petty man cultivates perverse qi—
hence, the Sage acts without doing,
and so meets no ruin.
He does not grasp,
and so meets no loss.
Act without doing,
and so meet no ruin—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Those who delight in licentious rites,
heedless of future calamity,
are perverse qi—
thus it is said: *without doing, there is no ruin.*
Do not grasp,
and so meet no loss—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
In the latter age, those who cling to ghosts and gods,
heedless of future calamity,
are perverse qi—
thus it is said: *without grasping, there is no loss.*

The people’s undertakings
often falter just as they near completion.
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The origins of calamity and fortune are subtle and unseen;
the petty man does not know the gates of misfortune—
he stirs and falls into guilt,
unmindful of his subtle desires.
To be cautious at the end as at the beginning,
then there will be no ruined undertakings.
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious*—*Chapter of the Talisman*—says:
States fall from losing their governance,
filial piety wanes from lacking completion,
misfortune arises from grasping action,
illness stems from carelessness—
thus, to be cautious at the end as at the beginning,
there will be no ruined undertakings.

Therefore, the Sage, as *The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says,
*"The Sage perceives their beginning and end—
it cannot be neglected."*

Desire not what should not be desired.
*The Scripture of the Southern Flower*—*The Zhuangzi*—says:
Ancient men desired,
but desired what they could not desire—
their desire reached the Dao itself.
They did not prize hard-to-obtain wealth;
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Ancient men did not prize hard-to-obtain wealth,
nor value useless things.

Study not what should not be studied.
*The Scripture of the Southern Flower*—*The Zhuangzi*—says:
Ancient scholars studied,
but studied what they could not study—
their study reached the Dao itself.

Return to the faults of the common people.
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
In ancient times, toward virtue,
they did not slight the small and so failed to practice it;
toward faults,
they did not overlook the subtle and so failed to correct them.
To aid the natural unfolding of all things,
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Ancient Sages of old
were in nature aligned with the Dao—
they knew without study,
saw without looking,
heard without listening—
the natural Way itself.
Yet they did not dare to act.
*The Scripture of the Southern Flower*—*The Zhuangzi*—says:
In ancient times, above and below alike,
there was no doing.

*The Classic of the Dao and Virtue*—*Four Children’s Commentary on the Ancient Way*—Volume Eight concludes.
Volume Nine begins.

chunks.original_text: 古襄寇才质集 古之善为道章第六十五 此章《南华经》言：上古大道至德之世，不尚贤，不使能，上如摽枝，民如野鹿。 端正而不知以为义，相爱而不知以为仁，实而不知以为忠，当而不知以为信。 蠢动而相使不以为赐，是故行而无迹，事而无传，民朴易治也。 古之善为道者， 《南华经》曰：玄古之君，天下无为也，天德而已矣。 非以明民， 《通玄经》曰：至忠复朴，民无伪匿。 将以愚之。 《南华经》曰：南越有邑焉，名为建德之国，其民愚而朴，则易治矣。 民之难治， 《南华经》曰：今周学智巧文华，不足以定天下，民难治矣。 以其智多。 《南华经》曰：上诚好智而无道，则天下大乱矣。 故桀纣天下每每大乱，罪在於好智。 今民之难治，以其智多也。 故以智治国，国之贼， 《通玄经》曰：是故以智为治者，任一人之才难以持国。 为智惠者则生奸，奸俗，亡国之风也，故以智治国，国之贼。 不以智治国，国之福。 《通玄经□道原篇》曰：古者不以智治国，国之福。 知此两者 《南华经》曰：去小智而大智明矣。 亦楷式。 《通玄经》曰：以文智虑为治者，苦心而无功。 独任其智，失则多矣。 好智穷术也，以智生患。 以智备之，譬犹挠水而欲求清也，难矣。 知其治之本者，去巧智而已，无为自化。 常知楷式， 《通玄经》曰：今欲学其道，不得清明玄圣，专守文籍，必不能为治矣。 是谓玄德。 《通玄经》曰：古者圣人执玄德於心，而化驰若神。 唯同乎大和持自然应者为能有治，是谓玄德。 玄德深矣远矣， 《通玄经□自然篇》曰：上古圣人与天地相保，公正修道，人道深即德深，德深即功名遂成，此谓玄德深矣远矣。 与物反矣， 《通玄经》曰：其与物反矣。

**Chapter Sixty-Five: Ancient Virtue in the Dao**

In the age of ancient great virtue and supreme Dao,
*The Southern Flower* speaks:
The Sage did not exalt the worthy,
nor employ the capable.
Above, like pruning branches,
the people were wild as deer.

Rectitude was natural—no need to call it *yi* (righteousness),
mutual love—no need to call it *ren* (benevolence),
sincerity—no need to call it *zhong* (loyalty),
truthfulness—no need to call it *xin* (faithfulness).
They moved clumsily yet guided one another—no need to call it a blessing.
Thus, they acted without leaving traces,
accomplished deeds without leaving records—
the people were simple and easy to govern.

Those ancient masters of the Dao—
*The Southern Flower* says:
The Sovereigns of the Mysterious Age
governed with *wuwei* (non-action),
merely embodying Heaven’s virtue.

Not to enlighten the people,
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Supreme loyalty restored simplicity—
the people harbored no deceit or concealment.
Rather, they sought to befuddle them.

*The Southern Flower* says:
In the southern lands, there was a village
named *Jiàn Dé* (Established Virtue),
its people simple and unrefined—
thus, they were easy to govern.

The difficulty in governing the people—
*The Southern Flower* says:
Now, the Zhou promote cleverness, skill, and ornamental culture—
insufficient to stabilize the realm.
The people are difficult to govern
because their intelligence is excessive.

*The Southern Flower* says:
If the ruler sincerely favors cleverness yet lacks the Dao,
the world falls into great disorder.
Thus, Jie and Zhou each brought chaos—
their crime lay in their love of cleverness.
Now, the people are difficult to govern
because their intelligence is excessive.

Thus, governing with cleverness is the ruin of the state.
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Those who govern with cleverness
rely on one man’s talent—
hard to sustain the state.
If they favor clever stratagems,
they breed deceit and corruption—
the winds that destroy nations.
Thus, governing with cleverness is the ruin of the state.
Not governing with cleverness is the state’s blessing.

*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious [Original Dao]* says:
Ancients did not govern with cleverness—
the state’s blessing.

To know these two truths—
*The Southern Flower* says:
Abandon petty cleverness, and great wisdom shines forth.
This is the model.

*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Those who govern with literary cleverness
labor in vain with weary hearts.
Relying solely on cleverness,
failures multiply.
To love cleverness is to exhaust artifice—
cleverness breeds calamity.
To counter cleverness with cleverness
is like stirring water to seek clarity—
difficult indeed.

Those who know the root of governance
abandon artifice and cleverness,
letting *wuwei* transform naturally.
Always hold to the model—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Now, if one seeks to learn the Dao
without attaining the pure, luminous, and sacred,
merely clinging to texts,
they cannot govern at all.
This is called *xuán dé* (Mysterious Virtue).

*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Ancient Sages held *xuán dé* in their hearts,
and their transformations moved like spirits.
Only those who harmonize with the Great Unity
and naturally respond can govern—
this is called *xuán dé*.
Mysterious Virtue is profound and vast—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious [Natural Dao]* says:
Ancient Sages preserved themselves with Heaven and Earth,
upright in cultivating the Dao.
The deeper the human path, the deeper the virtue;
the deeper the virtue, the more complete the achievements—
this is called *xuán dé*, profound and vast.
They inverted with things—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Their inversion with things was complete.

chunks.original_text: 注云：长处不智，故谓反矣。 然后乃至大顺。 《南华经》曰：与天地相合，其合缗缗，若愚若昏，是谓玄德，同乎大顺。 江海为百谷王章第六十六 此章《通玄经》言：上古圣人以道镇之，退而勿有，法於江海，不为其大，功名自化，故能成其王。 人之情性，心服於德，不服於力。 德在让不在争，是以古之圣人，欲责於人者先贵於人，欲尊於人者先尊於人，欲胜人者先自弱，欲卑人者先自卑。 故贵贱尊卑，道以制之，以其言下人，以其身后人，即天下乐推而不厌，戴而不重，此德重有余而气顺也。 故知与之为取，后之为先，即几於道矣。 德施天下，守之以让，先王所以守天下，故能长久，法海让王也。 江海所以能为百谷之王者， 《通玄经□自然仓》曰：江海洼下，百川归之，能成其广。 以其善下之，故能为百谷王。 《通玄经》曰：江海因下为之，天池即渊德，鱼鳖归焉。 故海不让东流，大之至也。 是以圣人 《通玄经》曰：江海处地之不足，故天下归之奉之。 圣人卑谦辞让者，见下也。 见下，故能致其高，矜者不立。 《南华经》曰：昔者尧舜让而帝之，汤武争而王之，白公争而灭之。 欲上人，以其言下之， 《通玄经□道德篇》曰：欲上人者，必以其言下之。 天下必效其欢爱，莫不推让。 欲先人，以其身后之。 《通玄经》曰：欲先人者，必以其身后之。 天下进其仁义，而无苛气。 是以处上而人不重， 《通玄经□道原篇》曰：是以处上而人不重，居前而人不害，天下归之，奸邪畏之。 处前而人不害。 《通玄经》曰：居上而民不重，居前而人不害。 虽绝国殊俗，蛆飞蠕动，莫不亲爱也。 是以天下乐推而不厌。 《通玄经》曰：即天下乐推而不厌，无之而不通，无往而不遂，故为天下贵。 以其不争， 《通玄经□自然篇》曰：古之善为君者，法江海为下也。 江海洼下不争，百川归之，故莫能与之争。 故道不以雄武立，在天下推己，不在於自取。 不争，故莫能与之争。 故天下莫能与之争。 《通玄经》曰：常人之道多者不与，圣人之道卑而莫能上。 以其不争於万物也，故天下莫能与之争。 天下皆谓章第六十七 此章《通玄经》言：夫道者，约而能张，幽而能明，柔而能刚，含阴吐阳，而章三光。 日月以之行，山以之高，渊以之深，禽以之飞，兽以之走，麟以之游，凤以之翔。 以卑取尊，以亡取存，以退取先。 夫一曰慈，二曰俭，三曰不敢为天下先。 上古圣人守柔弗强，退而勿有，不敢骄奢，功名自化，故能成其王。 可以长久，三宝广大也。 天下皆谓我道大， 《通玄经》曰：我道无为，无所私受也。 似不肖。 《通玄经》曰：我德含愚，而容不肖。 夫唯大，故似不肖。 《通玄经》曰：古之善为君者，法江海无为，处不肖之地，故为天下王。 若肖久矣，其细也夫。 《通玄经》曰：古者圣王聪明智惠，守之以愚，无为而天下治。 我有三宝， 《通玄经》曰：我道有三宝，以卑取尊，以俭取广，以退取先。 保而持之。 《通玄经》曰：夫道者，以其保之。 一曰慈， 《通玄经》曰：天地之道，大以小为本，卑以自卫。 二曰俭， 《通玄经》曰：天地之道，多以少为始，俭以自固。 三曰不敢为天下先。 《通玄经》曰：天地之道，先以后为主，后以自让。

The Commentary says:
*"Long处* (prolonged) yet not *zhì* (wise/knowing), hence it is called *fǎn* (inversion).
Then it reaches *Dà Shùn* (Great Harmony).

*The Scripture of the South (Zhuangzi)* says:
When harmonizing with Heaven and Earth, their unity is seamless,
like the simplicity of the foolish and the dimness of the ignorant—
this is called *Mysterious Virtue*, in accord with *Great Harmony*.

**Chapter 66: The King of All Valleys (Jiānghǎi as King)**
This chapter of *The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* states:
In the ancient times, the Sage-Kings governed through the Dao/Way,
retiring yet without absence, modeling themselves after the rivers and seas—
not claiming greatness for themselves, their virtue naturally manifesting,
so they could establish their kingship.

Human nature and disposition
submit to virtue, not to force.
Virtue lies in yielding, not in contention—
thus the ancient Sage-Kings,
who wished to be honored by others, first honored others themselves;
who wished to be revered by others, first revered others;
who wished to overcome others, first made themselves weak;
who wished to be humble before others, first humbled themselves.

Thus high and low, reverence and humility,
the Dao/Way governs them—
speaking gently to others while placing themselves last,
so the world finds joy in promoting them without weariness,
and in bearing them without resentment—
this is virtue abundant and *qi* in harmony.

Thus knowing to yield is to take,
and to retreat is to lead—
this is near to the Dao/Way.

Virtue bestowed upon the world,
preserved through yielding,
was how the ancient Kings maintained the world—
thus they could endure long.
This is the virtue of the Sea yielding kingship.

**Why the rivers and seas can be kings of all valleys,**
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious [Natural Virtue/Compendium]* says:
The rivers and seas are low and humble,
yet all streams flow into them—
thus they achieve vastness.
Because they excel in yielding,
they can be kings of all valleys.

*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The rivers and seas yield because they are low,
the Heavenly Pool is the *Yuān Dé* (Abyssal Virtue),
and fish and turtles gather there.
Thus the sea does not contend with the eastward flow—
this is the utmost greatness.

Therefore, the Sage-Kings
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The rivers and seas occupy the Earth’s deficiencies,
so the world submits to and venerates them.
The Sage-Kings who practice humility, modesty, and yielding words—
this is seen as yielding.
Seen as yielding, thus they attain their loftiness;
the arrogant cannot stand.

*The Scripture of the South (Zhuangzi)* says:
Once upon a time, Yao and Shun yielded yet became emperors,
Tang and Wu contended yet became kings,
and the Duke of Bai contended yet perished.
To ascend over others, one must speak gently to them,
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious [Virtue/Compendium]* says:
To ascend over others,
one must necessarily speak gently to them.
The world must imitate their joy and love,
all must promote and yield.

To lead others, one must place oneself last,
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
To lead others,
one must necessarily place oneself last.
The world advances their benevolence and righteousness,
and there is no harsh *qi*.
Thus, though they occupy the highest position, others do not resent them,
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious [Dao/Way Origins]* says:
Thus, though they occupy the highest position, others do not resent them,
and though they stand foremost, others do not harm them—
the world submits to them, and the wicked fear them.
Though they stand foremost, others do not harm them.
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
To occupy the highest position while the people do not resent,
and to stand foremost while others do not harm—
even in distant lands and alien customs,
where maggots fly and worms writhe,
all are drawn to love them.
Thus the world finds joy in promoting them without weariness.
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Thus the world finds joy in promoting them without weariness,
without them, nothing is left undone,
without their leading, nothing fails to succeed—
hence they are held in highest esteem by the world.
Because they do not contend,
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious [Natural Virtue]* says:
The ancient skilled in ruling modeled themselves after the rivers and seas—
low and yielding, not contending.
All streams flow into them,
so none can contend with them.
Thus the Dao/Way does not stand upon strength and arms,
but upon the world’s promotion of them—
not upon their own seizing.
Because they do not contend,
none can contend with them.
Thus the world cannot contend with them.
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The Way of ordinary people is many and does not unite,
the Way of the Sage-Kings is humble yet none can surpass it.
Because they do not contend with all things,
the world cannot contend with them.

**The World All Praises (Chapter 67)**
This chapter of *The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* states:
The Dao/Way is simple yet expansive,
mysterious yet luminous,
soft yet strong—
containing yin and emitting yang,
and thus manifesting the three brilliances.

The sun and moon move through it,
mountains rise through it,
the abyss deepens through it,
birds fly through it,
beasts run through it,
the qilin roams through it,
and the phoenix soars through it.

To take reverence through humility,
to take survival through extinction,
to take precedence through retreat.

The first is *cí* (compassion),
the second is *jiǎn* (frugality),
the third is not daring to lead the world.

The ancient Sage-Kings preserved softness and did not grow rigid,
retired yet were not absent,
did not dare to be proud or extravagant—
their virtue naturally transformed,
so they could establish their kingship.
They could endure long,
and their three treasures were vast and expansive.

The world all praises my Dao/Way as great,
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
My Dao/Way is *wu wéi* (non-action),
and I do not privately receive what is unworthy.
It seems not to conform.
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
My virtue contains simplicity,
yet it tolerates the unworthy.
Only because it is great,
does it seem not to conform.
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The ancient skilled in ruling modeled themselves after the rivers and seas—
*wu wéi* (non-action), occupying unworthy positions,
so they became kings of the world.
If conformity were long sustained,
its subtlety would be lost.
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The ancient Sage-Kings were clear-sighted, wise, and benevolent,
yet they preserved themselves in simplicity,
practicing non-action while the world was governed.
I possess three treasures,
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
My Dao/Way has three treasures—
to take reverence through humility,
to take vastness through frugality,
to take precedence through retreat.
Preserving and holding them.
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The Dao/Way is preserved through them.

The first is compassion,
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The Dao/Way of Heaven and Earth,
great yet rooted in the small,
humble yet self-guarding.

The second is frugality,
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The Dao/Way of Heaven and Earth,
abundant yet beginning with the few,
frugal yet self-fortifying.

The third is not daring to lead the world,
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The Dao/Way of Heaven and Earth,
leading through retreat as its principle,
retiring to yield.

chunks.original_text: 夫慈，故能勇； 《通玄经》曰：上古圣人法道之卑者，所以自下也。 卑则尊，此天道之所成也。 俭，故能广； 《通玄经》曰：上古圣人法道之俭者，所以自少也。 俭则广，此天道之所成也。 不敢为天下先，故能成器长。 《通玄经》曰：上古圣人法道之退者，所以自后也。 退则先，此天道之所成也。 今舍其慈且勇， 《通玄经》曰：末世人性好强而恶弱，而不知失，强梁者亡。 舍其俭且广， 《通玄经》曰：末世人性好奢而恶俭，而不知失，骄奢者亡。 舍其后且先， 《通玄经》曰：末世人性好先而恶后，而不知失，争先者丧。 死矣。 《通玄经》曰：勇强之本，务在卑弱； 广用之本，务在俭约； 争先之本，务在谦退。 三者既失，国家丧亡。 夫慈，以战则胜， 《通玄经》曰：故道不以坚强胜，在天下自服，不在於自取，柔弱则胜。 以守则固。 《通玄经》曰：末世城高池深，不足以为固。 善守者，无与御。 天将梂之， 《通玄经》曰：天之道损盈而益寡。 《洞灵经》曰：道德盛则鬼神助，可谓有德者也。 以慈卫之。 《通玄经》曰：世治则以义卫身，世乱则以身卫义。 善为士者章第六十八 此章《南华经》言：魏武侯谓徐无鬼曰：吾欲爱民而为义偃兵，其可乎？ 徐无鬼曰：君兵如鹤列於丽谯门之间，阵无以徒骥於锱坛之宫，岂为偃兵？ 古者无藏逆於得，无以巧胜人，不以谋胜人，不以战胜人。 今夫杀人之士民，兼人之土地，以养吾和与吾神者，其战不知孰善？ 胜之恶乎在？ 君若勿已，为修胸中之诚，以应天地无为之情而不撄挠。 夫民死已脱矣，君将恶乎用夫偃兵哉。 古之善士者不武，善战者不怒。 用贤不争，天下太平也。 善为士者不武， 《洞灵经》曰：甲兵不足以恃强。 善战者不怒， 《通玄经》曰：古善用兵者畜其怒，怒畜而威可立也。 善胜敌者不争， 《通玄经》曰：善战者无与斗，乘时势，因民欲，而天下服。 善用人者为之下。 《通玄经》：古善用人者，若蚈之足众而不相害，若舌之与齿坚柔相摩而不相败。 夫夏后之璜不能无瑕，明月之珠不能无秽，然天下宝之者，贤人也，不以小恶妨大美。 夫志人之所短，忘人之所长，而欲求贤於天下，即难矣。 是谓不争之德， 《通玄经》曰：能得人心者，必自得者也； 能自得者，必柔弱者也。 能成霸王者，必胜者也； 能胜敌者，必德者也。 是谓用人之力， 《通玄经》曰：爱贤之谓仁，敬贤之谓礼。 是谓配天，古之极也。 《通玄经》曰：千乘之国行文德者，王； 万乘之国好用兵者，亡。 用兵有言章第六十九 此章《通玄经》言：用兵有五：有义兵，有应兵，有忿兵，有贪兵，有骄兵。 诛暴救弱，谓之义兵。 敌来加己，不得已而用之，谓之应兵。 争小故，不胜其心，谓之忿兵。 利人土地，欲人财货，谓之贪兵。 持其国家之大，矜其人民之众，欲见贤於敌国者，谓之骄兵。 义兵王，应兵胜，忿兵败，贪兵死，骄兵灭，此天之道也。 今战国乱臣贼子用兵轻敌＃1，掩袭不备，先僭致祸也，祸莫大於轻敌。 用兵有言： 《通玄经□上礼》曰：以奇用兵，奇逸为劳，奇饱为饥，奇静为动，奇治为乱，奇后为先。 何往而不胜？ 后者胜矣。

Thus, compassion brings forth courage—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The ancient sages followed the Dao’s humility,
so as to place themselves below others.
Humility yields honor—
this is the fulfillment of Heaven’s Way.

Frugality brings forth vastness—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The ancient sages followed the Dao’s frugality,
so as to begin with little.
Frugality yields abundance—
this is the fulfillment of Heaven’s Way.

Not daring to lead the world,
thus one attains the completion of great instruments and long reigns—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The ancient sages followed the Dao’s retreat,
so as to place themselves behind others.
Retreat yields precedence—
this is the fulfillment of Heaven’s Way.

Now, abandoning compassion and courage—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Men of the latter age love strength and hate weakness,
yet they do not know their loss—
the overbearing perish.

Abandoning frugality and vastness—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Men of the latter age love extravagance and hate frugality,
yet they do not know their loss—
the proud and wasteful perish.

Abandoning retreat and precedence—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Men of the latter age love to lead and hate to follow,
yet they do not know their loss—
those who contend for precedence are undone.
Death is near—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The root of reckless strength lies in humility and weakness;
the root of vast utility lies in frugality and restraint;
the root of striving for precedence lies in modesty and retreat.
When these three are lost, states perish and fall.

Compassion—
in war, it brings victory—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The Dao does not conquer through strength,
but through the world’s spontaneous submission,
not through self-assertion.
Softness and weakness prevail.

In defense, it makes firm—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
High walls and deep moats are insufficient for true defense.
The skillful guardian needs no walls.
Heaven will protect it—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Heaven’s Way diminishes the full and benefits the few.
*The Scripture of the Cavern Spirit* says:
When virtue and Dao flourish, spirits and gods assist—
this is the mark of the virtuous.

Compassion guards it—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
In times of order, righteousness guards the body;
in times of chaos, the body guards righteousness.

**Chapter Sixty-Eight: The Virtuous Warrior**
This chapter from *The South Flower Scripture* recounts:
Wei Wu Hou asked Xu Wu Gui:
*"I wish to love the people and practice righteousness while laying down arms—is this possible?"*
Xu Wu Gui replied:
*"Your armies stand like cranes at the ornate gate,
your formations do not rely on swift horses at the hallowed hall—
how can this be called laying down arms?
In ancient times, there was no storing of weapons for gain,
no outwitting others through cleverness,
no defeating others through schemes,
no conquering others through war.
Now, those who slaughter the people and seize their lands,
to nourish their own harmony and spirits—
who among them knows the art of war?
Where lies victory?
If you cannot cease, then cultivate sincerity within your breast,
responding to Heaven and Earth’s effortless nature without resistance.
When the people die, they are already freed—
what use is there in laying down arms?
The ancient virtuous warriors were not martial,
the skilled fighters did not rage.
Using the worthy without contention,
the world attains great peace.

The virtuous warrior is not martial—
*The Scripture of the Cavern Spirit* says:
Armor and weapons are insufficient for strength.

The skilled fighter does not rage—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The ancient masters of war stored their anger;
when anger was stored, their威 *wei* could be established.

The one who bests enemies does not contend—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The skilled warrior fights no one,
but rides the currents of time and follows the people’s desires—
and the world submits.

The master of men serves below—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The ancient masters of men were like the many feet of a centipede,
each aiding without harming,
or like the tongue and teeth—
firm and yielding, grinding without destruction.

Though the summer jade may have flaws,
and the moon’s pearl may bear blemishes,
yet the world treasures them—
the worthy do not let minor faults obscure great beauty.
To fixate on others’ shortcomings,
forgetting their virtues,
and yet seek the worthy in the world—
this is difficult indeed.

This is called the virtue of non-contention—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Those who win the hearts of men must first win themselves;
those who win themselves must be soft and weak.
Those who achieve hegemony and kingship must first be conquerors;
those who conquer must be virtuous.

This is called the power of using men—
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
To love the worthy is benevolence;
to respect the worthy is ritual.

This is called aligning with Heaven—
the ancient ultimate.

*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
A thousand-chariot state practicing cultural virtue becomes king;
a ten-thousand-chariot state fond of war perishes.

**Chapter Sixty-Nine: The Five Kinds of War**
This chapter from *The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
There are five kinds of war:
There is the righteous war,
there is the responsive war,
there is the wrathful war,
there is the greedy war,
and there is the arrogant war.

To punish tyranny and rescue the weak—this is the righteous war.
When an enemy attacks and there is no alternative—this is the responsive war.
To quarrel over trifles, unable to master one’s own heart—this is the wrathful war.
To covet another’s land, to desire another’s wealth—this is the greedy war.
To boast of one’s state’s grandeur and people’s multitude,
and to seek superiority over enemy states—this is the arrogant war.

The righteous war brings kingship,
the responsive war brings victory,
the wrathful war brings defeat,
the greedy war brings death,
the arrogant war brings annihilation—
this is Heaven’s Way.

Now, the warring states’ rebellious ministers and traitors
use war lightly against enemies,
ambush the unprepared,
and first invite disaster—
no calamity is greater than underestimating the enemy.

There is a saying about war:
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious [Upper Section on Rites]* says:
To use the unusual in war,
the unusual becomes weary as if labored,
the unusual becomes hungry as if starved,
the unusual becomes restless as if disturbed,
the unusual becomes chaotic as if disordered,
the unusual becomes forward as if retreating.
Where does one go without victory?
The latter prevails.

chunks.original_text: 吾不敢为主 《通玄经》曰：先唱者，穷之路也。 而为客， 《通玄经》曰：后动者，建之源也。 不敢进寸 《通玄经》曰：屈者，所以求伸也。 而退尺。 《通玄经》曰：屈寸以伸尺，君子为之。 是谓行无行， 《通玄经》曰：举兵以为人者，众助之； 以自为者，众去之。 攘无臂， 《通玄经》曰：众之所助，虽弱必强。 仍无敌， 《通玄经》曰：众之所去，虽大必立。 执无兵。 《通玄经》曰：古者怀制胜利於不战而罢兵也，诸侯宾伏，此用兵之上也。 祸莫大於轻敌， 《通玄经》曰：武勇以强梁死，辩士以智能困。 能以智而知胜，不能以智不知其败。 勇於一能，察於一辞，可与曲说，未可广应。 轻敌则几丧吾宝。 《通玄经˙上德篇》曰：老子观影而知持后，后动者未尝失宜。 故圣人曰：无因循，常后而不先。 譬若积薪，后者为上。 故抗兵相加， 《通玄经》曰：闻敌国之君有暴厉其民者，即举兵而临其境，而敌相当欲交兵接刃，后者胜矣。 哀者胜矣。 《通玄经》曰：所谓后者，圣人守静道，拘雌节，因循而应变，常后而不先，功大靡坚，不能与争也。 后者胜矣。 吾言甚易知章第七十 此章《冲虚经》言：商太宰见孔子曰：丘圣者欤？ 孔子曰：圣则丘何敢，然则丘博学多识者也。 商太宰曰：三王圣者欤？ 孔子曰：三王善任智勇者，圣则丘不知。 太宰曰：五帝圣者欤？ 孔子曰：五帝善任仁义者，圣则丘弗知。 太宰曰：三皇圣者欤？ 孔子曰：三皇善任因时者，圣则丘弗知。 商太宰大骇曰：然则孰者为圣？ 孔子动容有问曰：西周之人太史老聃有圣者焉、不治而不乱，不言而自信，不化而自行，蔷荡乎民无能名焉，可谓大圣人矣。 故老圣曰：吾言大道，无为之化也。 吾言 《南华真经》曰：老聃明白於天地无为简易之德者，此之谓大宗大本大宗师也。 甚易知， 《通玄经》曰：治大国者，道不可小。 国地广者，制不可狭。 王位高者，事不可烦。 治民众者，教不可苛。 事烦难治，法苛难行，求寡难赡，大较易为之智，曲辩难为治。 故无益於治，有益为乱者，圣人不为也。 无益於用，有益於费者，智不行也。 故功不厌约，事不厌省，求不厌寡。 功约易成，事省易治，求寡易赡。 其易行。 《通玄经》曰：河以逶迤，故能远； 山以陵迟，故能高； 道以优游，故能化。 夫通於一技，审於一事，察於一能，可以曲说，末可广应於治要也。 道之言曰：芒芒昧昧，与天同气。 同气者帝，同义者王，同功者霸，无一焉者亡。 故不言而治，无事而化，是以天心动化无为者也。 故有道以治之法、事少足以治，无道以治之法，事多足以乱。 天下 《通玄经》曰：末世天下民甚拘於小好而塞於大道，不能知行也。 莫能知， 《通玄经》曰：末世小学蔽德不能知也。 《南华经》曰：古者德固不小识，后世小识伤德，不能知也。 莫能行。 《通玄经》曰：末世小善塞道，不能行也。 《南华经》曰：古者道固不小行，后世小行伤道，不能行也。 言有宗， 《通玄经□微明篇》曰：言有宗，事有君，至言去言。 事有君。 《通玄经□精诚篇》曰：言有宗，事有本，至为去为。 夫唯无知， 《通玄经》曰：末世小学，争鱼者濡，逐驮者趋，浅之人所争者，末矣，夫唯无知。

I dare not act as master.

*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The one who strikes first is on the path to exhaustion.

Yet as a guest, *The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The one who moves last is the source of establishment.

I dare not advance even an inch,
but retreat a foot.

*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
To bend an inch to extend a foot—this is the way of the virtuous.

This is called "action without action,"
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Raising an army for others brings their aid;
raising an army for oneself brings their departure.

There is no arm to ward off,
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Where the multitude aids, though weak, it must grow strong.

There is no enemy to oppose,
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Where the multitude departs, though great, it must stand firm.

There is no weapon to grasp.
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The ancients held victory and triumph in not waging war while yet disbanding armies—when lords and vassals were in submission, this was the highest use of war.

No calamity is greater than underestimating the enemy,
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The bold and courageous die by their reckless strength;
the eloquent and clever are constrained by their own cleverness.
One who knows victory through cleverness is capable;
one who does not know defeat through cleverness is not.

Brave in one act, discerning in one word,
one may be persuaded by subtle arguments,
but not yet trusted to broad application.

Lightly underestimating the enemy almost loses one’s treasure.

*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious • Upper Virtue Section* says:
Laozi observed shadows to know the principle of yielding last—
the one who moves last never fails in propriety.

Hence the Sage says:
"Do not follow convention;
always yield last and never strike first.
Like stacking firewood,
the last is the highest.

Thus when armies clash,
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
If one hears that a sovereign of an enemy state is oppressing his people with cruelty,
he should raise his army and approach its borders.
When the enemy is ready to engage and meet in battle,
the one who yields last will prevail.
The compassionate will prevail."

*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The so-called "one who yields last"
is the Sage who guards the Dao of stillness,
restrains the feminine principle,
follows convention while responding to change,
always yields last and never strikes first—
his great achievements are without rigidity,
and he cannot be contested.
The one who yields last will prevail.

My words are found in *The Chapter of Easy Knowing*, the seventy-first chapter.
This chapter of *The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* states:
The商太宰 saw Confucius and said:
"Is Master Kong a Sage?"
Confucius replied:
"A Sage? How dare I claim such a title! Yet I am one who studies widely and knows much."

The商太宰 said:
"Are the Three Kings Sages?"
Confucius replied:
"The Three Kings were skilled in employing those of wisdom and courage—
whether they were Sages, I do not know."

The商太宰 said:
"Are the Five Emperors Sages?"
Confucius replied:
"The Five Emperors were skilled in employing those of virtue and righteousness—
whether they were Sages, I do not know."

The商太宰 said:
"Are the Three Sovereigns Sages?"
Confucius replied:
"The Three Sovereigns were skilled in adapting to the times—
whether they were Sages, I do not know."

The商太宰 was greatly startled and said:
"Then who is truly a Sage?"
Confucius, moved in expression, replied:
"In the Western Zhou, there was the Grand Historian Lao Dan, who may be called a Sage—
without governing yet without chaos,
without speaking yet self-assured,
without transforming yet self-directed,
he drifts among the people who cannot name him.
He may be called a great Sage indeed."

Hence the Old Sage said:
"My words speak of the Great Dao,
the transformation of non-action."

My words,
*The Southern Flower Canon* says:
"Lao Dan was clear about the virtue/power of Heaven and Earth,
their non-action, and their simplicity—
this is called the Great Ancestor, the Great Root,
the Great Master."

Easy to know,
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
To govern a great state, the Dao cannot be slighted.
When the land is vast, the measures cannot be narrow.
When the king’s position is exalted, the affairs cannot be burdensome.
When the people are many, the teachings cannot be harsh.
Burdensome affairs are difficult to govern,
harsh laws are difficult to enforce,
scant resources are hard to sustain—
this is where cleverness may be of little use,
and subtle arguments cannot bring order.

Hence what is not beneficial to governance,
what is beneficial yet causes disorder—
the Sage does not do this.

What is not beneficial to war,
what is beneficial yet causes waste—
the wise do not employ this.

Thus, achievements are not weary of being frugal,
affairs are not weary of being simplified,
demands are not weary of being few.
Frugal achievements are easy to complete,
simplified affairs are easy to govern,
few demands are easy to sustain—
this is easy to practice.

*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The River flows with winding ease, hence it can reach far;
The Mountain rises with gradual ascent, hence it can stand high;
The Dao proceeds with gentle leisure, hence it can transform.

He who is skilled in one technique,
proficient in one matter,
discerning in one ability—
may be persuaded by subtle arguments,
but cannot yet be broadly applied to governance.

The words of the Dao say:
Vague and indistinct,
it harmonizes with Heaven’s qi.
He who harmonizes with qi becomes an Emperor,
he who harmonizes with virtue becomes a King,
he who harmonizes with power becomes a Conqueror,
he who lacks any of these will perish.

Thus, without words yet governance is achieved,
without affairs yet transformation is complete—
this is why the heart of Heaven moves and transforms through non-action.

Hence, with the Dao to govern,
few affairs suffice for governance;
without the Dao to govern,
many affairs suffice only to bring disorder.

In the end times,
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
The people of the world are overly constrained by petty pleasures
and obstructed by the Great Dao,
unable to know or practice it.
None can know,
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
In the end times, petty learning obscures virtue,
and none can know it.

*The Southern Flower Canon* says:
In ancient times, virtue was not slighted by petty knowledge;
in later times, petty knowledge injured virtue,
and none could know it.

None can practice.
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
In the end times, petty goodness blocks the Dao,
and none can practice it.

*The Southern Flower Canon* says:
In ancient times, the Dao was not slighted by petty practice;
in later times, petty practice injured the Dao,
and none could practice it.

Words have a root,
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* [• *Clarifying the Mysterious Section*] says:
Words have a root,
affairs have a master—
the highest words transcend words.
Affairs have a master,
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* [• *Sincere Integrity Section*] says:
Words have a root,
affairs have a foundation—
the highest practice transcends practice.

He who lacks knowledge alone,
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
In the end times, petty learning—
those who vie for fish are drenched,
those who chase beasts are exhausted,
the shallow concerns of the vulgar—
these are the ends of things.
He who lacks knowledge alone."

chunks.original_text: 是以不我知。 《通玄经》曰：末世小道，失其宗本，技能虽多，濡沬浅涸，不如寡言，害众着任而使断其指，以明大巧之不可为也，是以不我知。 知我者稀， 《冲虚经》曰：西周之人太史老聃有圣者焉，不治而不乱，不言而自信，不化而自行，荡荡乎民无能名焉，可谓大圣人矣。 则我者贵。 《通玄经》曰：幽凭玄默，无为而治，不知所为而功自成者，圣人也。 所贵乎道者，贵其龙变也，唯神化为贵。 是以圣人， 《南华经》曰：不离於宗谓之天人。 以天为宗，以德为本，以道为门，兆於变化，谓之圣人。 被褐怀玉。 《通玄经》曰：玉在山而草木润，珠在渊而岸不桔，道在中而形自治。 知不知上章第七十一 此章《南华真经》言：道不欲杂，杂学士多，多则扰，扰则乱，乱则忧患斯起，忧而不能救。 其书学上贤也，以平教化，正狱讼； 贤者在位，能者在职，泽施於下，万民怀德。 至其衰也，朋党比周，各推其与，废公趣私，内外相举，奸者在位，贤者隐处。 古之道德有蔽塞在於诸子之书是者，儒家惠施、多方其书五车，其道舛驳，驳杂无治，其言也繁乱不中於用。 墨家墨翟、禽滑厘不与先王同，毁古之礼乐，墨子称禹道，将使彼世之墨者必自劳苦。 名家宋钘、尹文作为华山之冠以自表，以为无益於天下。 法家彭蒙、田骈、慎到之道非生人之行，而至於死人之理。 公孙龙纵横辩者之徒，能以辩服人口，不能以辩服人之心，皆书学巧智教民伪端，而纵之於僻邪淫＃2，而弃之以法，随之以刑，虽残贼天下，不能禁其奸也。 独在巧智，失则多矣，好智穷术也，以智治国，国之贼。 山生金，石生玉，反相剥； 木生虫，还自食； 人生学，还自乱。 上多学，下多事； 上多事，下烦乱。

Thus, none truly know me.
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
In the end times, petty Dao is abandoned,
its root and foundation lost.
Though skills may be many,
they are shallow, muddled, and dry—
better to speak little.
To harm the multitude by burdening them with tasks
and then sever their fingers to demonstrate
that great skill cannot be forced—
thus, none truly know me.

Few know me,
*The Scripture of the Void and Emptiness* says:
In the Western Zhou, the Grand Historian Lao Dan was a sage—
he ruled without governing, spoke without persuading,
transformed without teaching,
and drifted effortlessly, beyond the people’s naming.
Truly, he was a great sage.

Those who follow me are honored.
*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
In silent repose, in profound stillness,
governing through non-action,
unaware of doing yet deeds accomplished—
this is the sage.
What is honored in the Dao is its dragon-like transformation,
for divine transformation alone is noble.

Thus, the sage,
*The Scripture of the South* says:
Does not stray from the root—
this is the Heavenly Human.
Taking Heaven as root,
virtue as foundation,
the Dao as gate,
manifesting in transformation—
this is the sage.
Clad in coarse robes yet holding jade.

*The Scripture of Penetrating the Mysterious* says:
Jade in the mountains makes grasses flourish,
pearls in the depths keep shores from withering,
the Dao within brings form to self-regulation.

**Chapter 71: "Knowing the Unknown"**
This chapter of *The True Scripture of the South* speaks:
The Dao does not desire mixture.
Scholars of many schools abound;
many, they disturb;
disturbed, they are disordered;
disorder brings sorrow and calamity.
Sorrowed, they cannot be saved.

Their books teach the virtuous:
to level instruction, to rectify lawsuits.
The worthy govern, the capable serve—
benevolence spreads below, and the people cherish virtue.
But when it decays,
cliques form, each promoting their own,
abandoning the public for private gain,
inner and outer factions rise,
the deceitful take office, the worthy hide away.

In ancient times, the Dao and virtue were obscured
in the books of the Hundred Schools.
The Confucians—Hui Shi and Du Shi—
their writings filled five chariots,
their teachings contradictory and tangled,
their words chaotic and useless.
The Mohists—Mo Di and Jin Hui—
did not align with the ancient kings,
abolishing the rites and music of old,
Mo Zi extolling Yu’s Way,
forcing his followers into laborious toil.

The Logicians—Sun Pin and Yin Wen—
crafted the *Hua Mountain Cap* to display themselves,
claiming it benefited nothing in the world.
The Legalists—Peng Meng, Tian Pian, and Shen Dao—
their teachings did not suit the living,
but only the logic of the dead.
The Sophists—Gongsun Long and his disciples—
could persuade with words but not with truth,
all teaching cleverness and deceit,
indulging in perverse and licentious ways,
then abandoning them to law, following with punishment.
Though they ravaged the world, they could not curb their treachery.

Skill alone is perilous,
and when lost, it multiplies.
To love knowledge and exhaust technique—
to govern with knowledge is to ruin the state.

Mountains yield gold, stones yield jade,
yet they erode each other;
trees breed worms, which devour them;
humans study, yet only bring chaos.
The more the ruler studies, the more the people labor;
the more the ruler acts, the more the people are troubled.

Thus, to stop the boiling with firewood only makes the boiling worse—
one who knows the principle of *wuwei* governance knows to remove the fire alone.
*Wuwei* naturally aligns itself.

Now, the teachings of the various schools—perverse doctrines and deceitful words—
are the very obstructions that bring chaos to the world.

To know what one does not know—
the *Tongxuan Jing*[*Symptoms of the Mysterious*] says:
*"The ancient sages who skillfully employed the Dao
let *wuwei* transform itself naturally,
and thus never caused harm.
Therefore it is said: To know what one does not know—*shàng* [superior]."*

To not know what one knows—
the *Tongxuan Jing* says:
*"Now, those who do not know the Dao
actively interfere, bringing self-ruin.
Fortune becomes misfortune.
Therefore it is said: To not know what one knows—*disease*."*

Only the diseased who recognize their disease—
the *Tongxuan Jing* says:
*"The common people and lesser scholars all indulge in book-learning for profit,
profiting from learning while unaware that their disease is their disease."*

Thus, they are not truly diseased—
the *Nanhua Jing*[*Southern Flower Sutra*] says:
*"Nan Rong Zhi said: When a villager falls ill,
and others ask about it, the sick person can name their ailment—
how could they not be ill?
The Sage is not ill,
yet those who recognize their disease—
even they are not truly ill.
For by recognizing their disease,
the *Nanhua Jing* says:
as if Zhi had drunk medicine to worsen his illness—
they can remove the disease of being diseased,
and thus are not ill.
Therefore, they are not ill."*

The *Tongxuan Jing* says:
*"Only the ancient sages knew that the disease of disease is no disease.
The people do not fear coercive laws—
this chapter of the *Tongxuan Jing* says:
The ancient sages governed with the Dao,
maintaining softness without force,
allowing virtue to transform naturally,
and thus achieved their kingship.
Human nature responds to virtue, not to force.
Virtue comes from within—
self-love enables nobility,
and love for the people brings kingship,
so all under heaven return.
When the people do not fear coercion,
true awe naturally arises.
The *Chongxu Jing*[*Sutra of the Void*] says:
Yet to desire others to revere you—
this is impossible to attain through the Dao.
If others do not revere you,
how can danger or humiliation reach you?

Do not narrow your dwelling—
the *Nanhua Jing* says:
The enclosures of the Weishi clan,
the hunting grounds of the Yellow Emperor,
the palaces of Tang and Yu,
the halls of Tang and Wu—
as virtue declines, their dwellings grow ever narrower.

Do not exhaust what sustains you—
the *Tongxuan Jing* says:
*"To govern a great state, the Dao must not be constrained.
The broader the land, the broader the governance must be.
An emperor who cannot win the people cannot achieve the world;
one who wins the people but loses the Dao cannot retain it.
Only the unbounded remains unbounded."
The *Chongxu Jing* says:
*"Laws and measures are within oneself;
examination lies with the people.
If the people love me, I must love them in return;
if the people hate me, I must hate them in return.
Thus, the Sage—
the *Chongxu Jing* says:
Tang and Wu loved the world, so they ruled;
Jie and Zhou hated the world, so they perished.

Self-knowledge—
the *Tongxuan Jing* says:
*"The foundation of winning the people lies in self-knowledge.
When one blames others for their faults,
does one truly know oneself?
Not seeing oneself—
the *Tongxuan Jing* says:
Thus, the Sage does not force,
and so achieves kingship.
Self-love—
the *Tongxuan Jing* says:
*"No virtue surpasses loving others;
to love others is to have no grievance with punishment."
Not esteeming oneself—
the *Tongxuan Jing* says:
*"Thus, the Sage loves themselves,
and so achieves nobility.
Therefore, abandon that and take this.
Heaven’s calamities do not arise—
those who attain this are blessed.
Forgotten is that,
and guilt departs while fortune arrives."*

chunks.original_text: 勇於敢则杀章第七十三 此章《通玄经》言：七国用兵，杀无罪之民，养不义之主，害莫大也。 肆一人之意，忘海内之患，此天伦所取也，民之所雠，天之所诛。 故勇於敢则杀，天之所恶，孰知其故。 天网恢恢，而不失也。 勇於敢则杀， 《通玄经˙道德篇》曰：末世战国有利害之心，本有杀意，故勇於敢则杀。 勇於不敢则活。 《冲虚经》曰：夫行道者，使人虽勇刺之不入，虽巧击之不中。 夫刺之不入，击之不中而犹辱也，未若古圣人使人，虽勇不敢刺，虽巧不敢击。 夫不敢者，非无其杀意也，未若圣人本无其杀意也。 夫无其杀意也，未有爱利之心也，遂使天下丈夫女子莫不欢然，皆欲爱利之，不敢杀也。 若然无杀意者，无地而为君，无官以为长，是天下莫不愿安利之，故勇於不敢则活。 知此两者，或利或害。 《通玄经》曰：好勇，危亡之道，武勇以强梁死。 天之所恶，谁知其故？ 《冲虚经》曰：老聃语关尹曰：天之所恶，谁知其故？ 是以圣人犹难之。 《通玄经》曰：天下莫易於为善，所谓为善者，则静而无为，故为善易也。 天下莫难於为不善，所谓不善者，篡弒矫诈，非人之性，故为不善难也。 天之道， 《通玄经》曰：天之道损盈而益寡，鬼神之道骄溢不与。 不争而善胜， 《通玄经》曰：有阴德者，必有阳报； 有隐行者，必有明召。 种黍者不获谷，树恶者无报德。 不言而善应， 《通玄经》曰：为不善於显明之中者，人得而诛之； 为不善於幽暗之中者，鬼得而诛之。 不召而自来， 《通玄经》曰：夫天道，冬日之阳，夏日之阴，万物归之而莫之使，极自然至精之感，不召而来，不去而往。 繟然而善谋。 《通玄经》曰：天道坦坦，去身不远。 苟向善，虽过无怨； 苟不向善，虽忠来恶。 天网恢恢， 《洞灵经》曰：禁网疏阔，则易避而难犯。 天网恢恢，疏而不失。 疏而不失。 《通玄经》曰：战国勇敌者，杀戮无罪，民之所雠，天之所诛也。 民常不畏死章第七十四 此章《南华经》言：五霸骤而语刑名赏罚，安能治人。 此有知治之刑具，非知治之要道，可用刑具於天下，不足以用安道於天下矣。 末世之法，高为量而罪不及也，重为任而罚不胜也，危为难而诛不敢也。 民困於三贵，饰智而诈上，犯邪而行危，虽峻法严刑，不能禁其奸。 兽穷则触，禽穷则啄，人穷则诈，此之谓也。 故五霸法烦刑峻，则民生诈，上多事，下多怨。 求多则得寡，禁多则胜少，故以汤止沸，沸乃益甚，知其无为治之本者，去火而已。 清静自正。 故五霸虐刑，自执罪人而杀之也。 代有司杀人，希有不伤其手矣。 民常不畏死， 《通玄经》曰：五霸严刑峻法不足以为威，杀戮不足以禁奸。 奈何以死惧之？ 《通玄经》曰：法刻刑诛者，非帝王之业也，棰楚繁用者； 非致远之节也。 若使人常畏死， 《通玄经》曰：五霸法烦刑峻则民生诈，上多求则下交争。 求多则得寡，禁多则胜少。 而为奇者， 《通玄经□下德篇》曰：末世之民饰智诈上，犯邪行危，虽峻法严刑，不能禁其奸。 兽穷则触，禽穷则啄，人穷则诈，此之谓也。 吾得执而杀之， 《通玄经》曰：古善为政者积其德，积德而民可化。 今为刑暴者则生乱，乱俗，亡国之风也。 孰敢？

「**Chapter 73: The Bold in Daring Bring Death**
This chapter of the *Tongxuan Jing* speaks of: Seven states waging war, slaying the innocent, nourishing the unrighteous, and causing harm beyond measure. Indulging one’s private desires while ignoring the calamities within the realm—this is what Heaven detests, and what the people resent, and what Heaven punishes. Thus, the bold in daring bring death; what Heaven abhors, who knows its reason?

The Heavenly Net is vast and far-reaching, yet it does not fail to ensnare. The bold in daring bring death, but the *Tongxuan Jing˙Dao De* says: In the latter days of the Warring States, men have hearts of profit and loss, and from the outset, they harbor murderous intent. Thus, the bold in daring bring death, while the bold in restraint bring life.

The *Chongxu Jing* says: Those who practice the Dao make others so that though they be bold enough to strike, the strike will not take hold; though they be clever enough to attack, the attack will not find its mark. Though they strike and do not take hold, though they attack and do not find their mark, yet they still bring shame—how much less so than the ancient Sages, who made others so that though they be bold, they dare not strike, and though they be clever, they dare not attack! Those who dare not strike are not without murderous intent, but how much less so than the Sages, who from the outset have no murderous intent at all! Those who have no murderous intent at all have not yet cultivated a heart of love and benefit. Thus, they make all men and women under Heaven—without exception—rejoice and willingly embrace love and benefit, yet they dare not kill. If such is the case, without murderous intent, there is no place where they are not rulers, no office where they are not leaders. All under Heaven willingly embrace peace and benefit, and so the bold in restraint bring life.

Understanding these two principles—one brings benefit, the other harm. The *Tongxuan Jing* says: To love daring is the Dao of peril and ruin; the bold and daring die by force and tyranny. What Heaven abhors, who knows its reason? The *Chongxu Jing* says: Laozi spoke to Guan Yin: *"What Heaven abhors, who knows its reason?"* Therefore, even the Sage finds it difficult.

Under Heaven, nothing is easier than doing good; what is meant by doing good is to remain still and take no action, and so doing good is easy. Under Heaven, nothing is harder than doing evil; what is meant by doing evil is usurpation and regicide, deceit and falsehood, which go against human nature, and so doing evil is hard. The Dao of Heaven, the *Tongxuan Jing* says: Heaven’s Dao diminishes the full and benefits the few; the Dao of ghosts and spirits is proud and overflowing, not to be shared.

Without contention yet achieving victory, the *Tongxuan Jing* says: Those with hidden virtue must have manifest reward; those with secret deeds must have clear response. The sower of millet does not reap grain; the planter of evil does not receive virtue in return. Without speech yet responding well, the *Tongxuan Jing* says: To do evil in the light of day, men may punish you; to do evil in darkness, ghosts may punish you.

Without summoning yet they come, the *Tongxuan Jing* says: The Dao of Heaven is the sun of winter and the shade of summer; all things return to it, yet none compel them. It reaches the utmost of natural and refined influence—coming without summoning, departing without being driven away. Thus, it is effortless yet good at planning.

The *Tongxuan Jing* says: Heaven’s Dao is broad and open; to abandon the self is not far. If one turns toward good, even if they err, there will be no resentment. If one does not turn toward good, even if they are loyal, they will bring misfortune. The Heavenly Net is vast and far-reaching, and the *Dongling Jing* says: *"If the prohibitive nets are sparse and wide, they are easy to evade yet hard to violate."* The Heavenly Net is vast and far-reaching, sparse yet never failing. Sparse yet never failing. The *Tongxuan Jing* says: In the Warring States, those who dare to fight kill the innocent; the people resent them, and Heaven punishes them.

**Chapter 74: The People Do Not Normally Fear Death**
This chapter of the *Nanhua Jing* speaks of: The Five Hegemons suddenly speaking of punishments and rewards, yet how can they govern the people? This is merely knowing the tools of governance, not the essential Dao of governance. One may use the tools of governance throughout the realm, but this is not enough to apply the Dao of governance throughout the realm.

The laws of the latter days set high standards yet fail to reach the guilty; impose heavy burdens yet punishments do not overcome them; create great difficulties yet executions are not dared. The people are burdened by these three evils, adorned with cleverness and deceiving their superiors, committing wickedness and courting danger. Even with harsh laws and severe punishments, they cannot suppress their deceit.

Wild beasts when cornered will strike; birds when cornered will peck; men when cornered will deceive—this is what is meant. Thus, the Five Hegemons’ harsh laws and severe punishments make the people crafty, and the rulers demand much while the people resent much. The more they demand, the less they receive; the more they prohibit, the fewer they overcome.

And so, to stop the boiling by adding more fire—though it seems a strange remedy—the *Tongxuan Jing* says: The essential principle of governance is to remove the fire itself. To be clear and still, to return to rectitude.

Thus, the Five Hegemons cruelly punish, taking the guilty into their own hands and killing them. Those who substitute for the officials in killing are rare indeed who do not soil their hands. The people do not normally fear death, and the *Tongxuan Jing* says: The Five Hegemons’ harsh laws and severe punishments are not enough to instill awe; killing the innocent is not enough to suppress deceit. How can you rely on death to instill fear?

If you wish to make the people fear death, the *Tongxuan Jing* says: The Five Hegemons’ harsh laws and severe punishments make the people crafty; the more the rulers demand, the more the people contend below. The more they demand, the less they receive; the more they prohibit, the fewer they overcome.

And yet, there are those who are strange, the *Tongxuan Jing□Xia De* says: The people of the latter days adorn themselves with cleverness and deceive their superiors, commit wickedness and court danger. chunks.original_text: 《通玄经》曰：先王之法，非所作也。 法宽刑缓，囹圄空虚，天下一俗，莫怀奸心，此圣人之恩也。 常有司杀者杀。 《通玄经》曰：古之置有司也，所以禁民，使不得恣也。 其立君也，所以制有司，使不得专行也。 法度道术，所以禁君，使不得横断也。 夫代司杀者杀，是谓代大匠斲。 《通玄经□上仁篇》曰：鲸鱼失水，则制於蝼蚁。 人君舍其所守，而与臣争事，则制於有司。 臣下藏智而不用，反以事专其上。 人君者不任能而好自为，则智日困而自负责，数穷於下则不能申理，智不足以为治，威不足以行刑，则无以与天下交矣。 夫代司杀者杀，是谓代大匠斲。 夫代大匠斲，希有不伤其手矣。 《通玄经》曰：人君喜怒形於心，嗜欲见於外，则守职者离正而阿上，有司枉法而从风。 赏不当功，诛不应罪，则上下乖心，君臣相怨，百官烦乱，而智不能解非誉萌生，而明不能照非己之失。 而反自责，则人主愈劳，人臣愈佚。 是以代大匠斲者，希有不伤其手。 民之饥章第七十五 此章《南华经》言：周学好智而无道，则天下乱矣。 何以知其然邪？ 夫弓弩毕弋机变之智多，则禽乱於上矣； 钩饵网罟罾笋之智多，则鱼乱於水矣； 削格罗落罝罘之智多，则兽乱於泽矣； 智诈渐毒，颉滑坚白鲜垢同异之变多，则俗乱於辩矣。 自古及今，桀纣天下每每大乱，罪在於好智。 今周学民巧难治也，而作是章焉。 民之饥， 《通玄经》曰：民有饥色，非命夭亡，饿殍而卒。 以其上食税之多， 《通玄经》曰：且民之为生也，一人踱来而耕，不益十亩，中田之收，不过四石，妻子老弱仰之以食，或时有水旱灾害之患，以奉上求，即人主愍之矣。 是以饥。 《通玄经》曰：末世贪夫暴君，涸鱼其下以适无极之欲，则百姓不被天和、履地德矣，是以民饥。 民之难治， 《南华经》曰：民之难治，以其智多。 以其上之有为， 《通玄经》曰：后世有为也，则为天下用而不足治。 上多欲则下多诛，上多事则下多态。 以学生事又以事止事，譬犹扬火而使无焚也，难矣。 故以汤止沸，沸乃益甚，知其治之本者，去火而已。 是以难治。 《通玄经》曰：上有为也，下亦有为也。

The *Tongxuan Jing* says: The laws of the ancient kings were not their own creation.
With laws broad and punishments lenient, the prisons stand empty, and the realm unified in custom—none harbor deceitful hearts. This is the benevolence of the Sage.

Let those who hold office kill when they must. The *Tongxuan Jing* says: In ancient times, officials were appointed to restrain the people, lest they act without restraint. The establishment of rulers was to control these officials, lest they act unilaterally. Laws, measures, and Daoist arts were to restrain the ruler, lest he act arbitrarily.

To take the place of the executioner and kill—this is called usurping the Master Carpenter’s axe.

The *Tongxuan Jing* [in the *Shangren* section] says: A whale cast upon dry land is dominated by an ant. When a ruler abandons his proper role and contests matters with his ministers, he is dominated by his officials. Ministers hoard their wisdom and do not employ it, yet instead usurp authority from above.

If a ruler does not entrust capable men but insists on acting himself, his wisdom grows ever more constrained while his burdens increase. When cornered by his subordinates, he cannot rectify matters. His wisdom proves insufficient for governance, his authority inadequate for enforcing law—thus he cannot engage with the realm.

To take the place of the executioner and kill—this is called usurping the Master Carpenter’s axe. And he who usurps the Master Carpenter’s axe will rarely escape unscathed.

The *Tongxuan Jing* says: When a ruler’s joys and angers manifest in his heart, and his desires are visible without, those who guard their posts abandon principle to curry favor, and officials pervert the law to follow the wind. Rewards fail to match merit, punishments fail to fit crimes—thus superior and subordinate grow estranged, ruler and minister harbor grudges, officials grow chaotic, and wisdom cannot resolve slander while clarity cannot illuminate one’s own faults. Instead, they blame themselves, and so the sovereign grows ever more weary while his ministers grow ever more insolent.

Thus, he who usurps the Master Carpenter’s axe will rarely escape unscathed.

**On the People’s Hunger (Chapter 75)**
This chapter of the *Nanhua Jing* states: When learning is prized for cleverness but lacks the Dao, the world falls into chaos. How do we know this is so?

When the cunning of bows, crossbows, snares, and mechanical traps abounds, the birds grow disordered above. When the cunning of hooks, baits, nets, and weirs abounds, the fish grow disordered in the waters. When the cunning of traps, snares, and pitfalls abounds, the beasts grow disordered in the marshes. When the cunning of deceit, poison, sophistry, and debates over *jiehua* (contradictions), *jianhua* (subtleties), *firmness*, *whiteness*, *freshness*, *filth*, and distinctions abounds, then customs grow disordered in argumentation.

From ancient times to today, tyrants like Jie and Zhou have repeatedly plunged the world into great chaos, and the fault lies in their love of cleverness. Now, the people of Zhou are skilled yet difficult to govern, and so this chapter is composed.

**On the People’s Hunger**
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: When the people show signs of hunger, it is not by fate that they perish young or die of starvation. It is because of the heavy taxes imposed upon them.

The *Tongxuan Jing* says: Moreover, in sustaining life, one man plows and does not increase ten *mu* of land. Even in a middle-quality field, the harvest does not exceed four *dan*. His wife, children, and aged dependents rely on this for sustenance. At times, there are calamities of flood or drought. When tribute is demanded, the ruler may pity them—but still, they hunger.

The *Tongxuan Jing* says: In the latter days, greedy tyrants drain their people like fish to satisfy their boundless desires, and so the common folk do not receive the harmonies of Heaven or the virtues of Earth. Thus, the people hunger.

**On the Difficulty of Governing the People**
The *Nanhua Jing* says: The people are difficult to govern because their cleverness is excessive.

The *Tongxuan Jing* says: In later ages, when rulers act, they exhaust the world’s resources yet fail to govern. When superiors desire much, inferiors suffer much. When superiors engage in many affairs, inferiors adopt many guises. To teach the people and then expect them to cease their ways is like fanning flames and hoping they will not burn—it is difficult.

Thus, to stop boiling by adding more water only makes it worse. Those who know the root of governance know to remove the fire. Hence, they are difficult to govern.

The *Tongxuan Jing* says: When superiors act, inferiors also act.

chunks.original_text: 书学开民伪端，而纵之放僻邪淫，而弃之以法，随之以刑，虽残贼天下； 不能禁其奸也，是以难治。 人之轻死， 《通玄经》曰：民有轻死，非命而亡，乐得不已，好求不止，刑共杀之。 以其求生之厚， 《通玄经》曰：末世暗主，求下不量其积，取民不裁其力，男女不得耕织之业，有旦无暮，君臣相疾，以奉上求，力勤财匮，是以轻死。 是以轻死。 《通玄经》曰：上好取而无量，即下贪财而无让，民贫苦而纷争生，是以轻死。 夫唯无以生为者， 《南华经》曰：古者上则重生，重生则轻利。 后世财不足则盗，盗窃之行，於谁责而可乎？ 责上好货不贵生也。 是贤於贵生。 《通玄经□九守篇》曰：夫唯无以生为者，即所以得长生。 民之生章第七十六 此章《通玄经》言：战国用兵，殚天下之财，赡一人之欲，祸莫深矣。 肆一人之欲，长海内之患，此天伦所不取也，民之所雠，天之所诛。 故兵强则灭，坚强者死之徒也，岂不灭矣。 民之生也柔弱， 《南华经》曰：人之生，和气聚为生。 其死也坚强。 《南华经》曰：人之死，气之散也，气散则死。 万物草木生也柔脆， 《通玄经》曰：物之生也，草木英华。 其死也枯槁。 《通玄经》曰：物之死也，草木枯朽。 故坚强者，死之徒； 《通玄经˙道原篇》曰：坚强者，死之徒也。 柔弱者，生之徒。 《通玄经》曰：柔弱者，生之徒也。 是以兵强则不胜， 《通玄经》曰：欲刚者，又以柔守之； 欲强者，必以弱守之。 积柔成刚，积弱成强，观其所积，以知存亡，故兵强则灭。 木强则共。 《通玄经》曰：木强则折，革强则裂。 强大处下， 《通玄经。

**On the Corruption of Learning and the Lightness of Death**

Scholarly learning opens the door to deceit among the people, yet when their licentious and perverse ways are unleashed, they are abandoned to the law and pursued by punishment—though this only ravages the world. Unable to curb their deceit, they are thus difficult to govern.

**On the Lightness of Death**
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: When the people grow light in death, they perish not by fate but by their own indulgence, ever seeking without restraint, ever desiring without end—until punishment kills them.

Because their craving for life is excessive,
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: In the latter ages, dim-witted rulers take from the people without measure, demand of them without limit, so that men and women cannot tend to farming and weaving. Their days are numbered, yet they labor endlessly to serve their superiors, their strength exhausted, their wealth depleted—thus they grow light in death.

Thus, the people grow light in death.
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: When superiors indulge in boundless taking, inferiors become avaricious without restraint. The people, impoverished and suffering, give rise to strife—thus they grow light in death.

Those who do not value life above all,
The *Nanhua Jing* says: In ancient times, rulers prized life, and prizing life, they held gain in light regard. In later ages, when wealth is scarce, theft arises—yet whom can one blame for this? Blame the rulers who value gain over life.

This is wiser than valuing life.
The *Tongxuan Jing* [Nine Guardians Chapter] says: Only those who do not value life above all can attain true longevity.

**On the People’s Lifespan (Chapter Seventy-Six)**
This chapter of the *Tongxuan Jing* speaks: In the Warring States, warfare drained the world’s resources to satisfy one man’s desires—what greater calamity could there be? To indulge one man’s desires is to prolong the suffering of the land, a transgression against Heaven’s order, a grievance of the people, a sin inviting Heaven’s retribution. Thus, the strong in arms perish, for the overmighty are doomed to destruction—how could they not perish?

The people’s birth is gentle and weak,
The *Nanhua Jing* says: Human life is the gathering of harmonious *qi*.
Their death is rigid and strong.
The *Nanhua Jing* says: Human death is the scattering of *qi*—when *qi* scatters, death comes.

All things—grasses and trees—are gentle and tender in life,
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: In their birth, plants flourish in bloom.
But rigid and withered in death.
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: In their death, plants wither and decay.

Thus, the rigid and strong are doomed to death,
The *Tongxuan Jing* [Dao Yuan Chapter] says: The rigid and strong are doomed to death.
The gentle and weak are destined to life.
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: The gentle and weak are destined to life.

Thus, the strong in arms cannot prevail,

Those who seek strength must guard with weakness.
Accumulated gentleness becomes rigidity,
Accumulated weakness becomes strength.
Observe what they accumulate to know their fate—
Thus, the strong in arms perish.

The rigid tree snaps,

The mighty fall from their height,

chunks.original_text: 上德篇》。 曰：老子仰视屋树，退而目川，树强木则居低屋，大则材居下。 柔弱处上。 《通玄经》老子曰：树小条则居高屋，弱材则处上，譬若积薪，小者为上。 天之道章第七十七 此章《通玄经》言：古者明君取下有节，自养有度，必计岁而收，量民积聚，知育余不足之数，然后取奉，如此即得承所受於天地，而离於饥寒之患。 其憯怛於民也，民有饥者，食不重味，民有寒者，冬不被裘。 与民同苦乐，即天下无哀民。 后世孰能以有余奉天下，唯古有道之君者，能养鳏寡孤独，法天济民也。 天之道， 《通玄经》曰：天之道，损盈而益寡。 其犹张弓乎？ 《通玄经》曰：弧弓为射，非弦而不能发； 天之为射，无弓必中。 高者抑之， 《通玄经□守弱篇》曰：天之道，而抑高也。 下者举之； 《通玄经》曰：天之道，而举下也。 有余者损之， 《通玄经》曰：天之道，损有余也。 不足者与之。 《通玄经》曰：天之道，补不足也。 天之道损有余补不足， 《通玄经》曰：天之道，损有余奉不足； 地之道，损高而益下。 人之道则不然， 《通玄经》曰：人君之道则不然，不同天道损益也。 损不足 《通玄经》曰：且民之为耕也，妻子老弱仰之以食，水旱灾害，税敛难输。 以奉有余。 《通玄经》曰：人主取民以奉上，求之有余矣。 孰能以有余奉天下？ 《通玄经》曰：末世贪主暴君，涸鱼其下以适无极之欲，则百姓饥寒，孰能奉不足矣。 唯有道者。 《南华经》曰：古者圣人，老弱孤寡为意，皆有所养。 是以圣人 《南华经》曰：古之人其备乎，育万物，泽及百姓。 为而不恃， 《通玄经》曰：天地之道，万物恃之以为，莫知其德。 功成不居， 《通玄经》曰：天地之道，万物功成不居，莫知其德。 其不欲见贤。 《通玄经》曰：圣人虚心无有也，见不足也。 见不足，故能成其贤。 天下柔弱章第七十八 此章《通玄经》言：海不让潦水，以成其大； 山林不让其枉桡，以成其荣； 圣人不辞其负薪之言，以广其名。 使言之而是，虽商夫刍荛犹不可弃也。 若言之而非，虽在人君卿相犹不可用也。 是非之处，不可以贵贱尊卑论也。 民沉溺而不忧者，君非贤主也。 守职死难，人臣之职也。 末世群臣效诚者稀，不用其身也。 竭力尽忠者，不能闻也。 是以古之圣人效法水之柔弱，含垢忍耻，受言纳谏。 为天下之主者，效水纳垢也。 天下柔弱者莫过於水， 《通玄经˙道原篇》曰：天下莫柔弱於水。 而攻坚强者 《通玄经》曰：夫水之为道也，利贯金石，强沦天下。 莫之能胜， 《通玄经》曰：夫水之为道也，行不可得穷极，微不可得把握。 其无以易之。 《通玄经》曰：夫水之为道也，击之无疮，刺之不伤，斩之不断，灼之不熏，淖约流循，不可靡散。 故柔胜刚， 《通玄经□上德篇》曰：老子见舌而守柔。 齿坚於舌，而先毙之。 弱胜强。 《通玄经》曰：积柔成刚，积弱成强。 不积而成，未之有也。 天下 《通玄经》曰：末世人之情性，皆好强而恶弱，好刚而恶柔，而不知失，不能柔弱也。 莫不知， 《通玄经》曰：君子察实，无信谗言。 君过而不谏，非忠臣也。 莫能行。 《通玄经》曰：谏而不听，君不明也。 是以圣人 《通玄经》曰：古之善为君者，法於水之柔弱。

**Chapter on Supreme Virtue (上德篇)**

The *Laozi* looked upward at the trees in the eaves, then gazed at the rivers below. The strong and rigid trees dwell in the lower eaves, the great in stature occupy the lower branches. The gentle and weak rise above.

The *Tongxuan Jing* says: The small and slender trees dwell in the higher eaves, the weak and slight occupy the upper branches—like stacking firewood, the smallest is placed on top.

**Chapter 77: The Dao of Heaven**
The *Tongxuan Jing* speaks: In ancient times, enlightened rulers governed with moderation, nurtured themselves with restraint, and calculated harvests according to the seasons. They measured the people’s stored provisions, knowing the surplus and deficit, then took only what was needed. Thus, they received what Heaven and Earth bestowed and avoided the suffering of hunger and cold.

When the people were distressed—those who starved ate food without relish, those who froze endured winter without furs—rulers shared in their hardships. Thus, there were no grieving subjects under Heaven.

In later ages, who could use their surplus to nourish the world? Only the ancient Dao-bearing rulers could sustain the widows, orphans, and the lonely, following Heaven’s way to aid the people.

The *Tongxuan Jing* says: The Dao of Heaven diminishes the full and benefits the scarce. Is it not like drawing a bow?

The *Tongxuan Jing* says: A bow is drawn for shooting, yet without a string, it cannot release. Heaven’s shooting requires no bow—it strikes true.

The high are humbled,
The *Tongxuan Jing* [Guard Weakness Section] says: The Dao of Heaven humbles the high.
The low are raised;
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: The Dao of Heaven raises the low.
The excessive are diminished,
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: The Dao of Heaven diminishes the excessive.
The deficient are supplemented.
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: The Dao of Heaven supplements the deficient.

The Dao of Heaven diminishes the excessive and supplements the deficient,
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: The Dao of Heaven diminishes the excessive to nourish the deficient.
The Dao of Earth diminishes the high and benefits the low.
But the Dao of humanity is otherwise,
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: The Dao of the ruler is otherwise, differing from Heaven’s diminishing and benefiting.

It diminishes the deficient,
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: Yet the people, in their tilling, rely on their wives, children, aged, and weak for sustenance. Facing floods, droughts, and heavy taxes, they struggle to provide.
To nourish the excessive.
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: The ruler takes from the people to serve above, seeking only the surplus.

Who can use their surplus to nourish the world?
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: In the later ages, greedy tyrants drain their people to satisfy boundless desires, leaving the masses hungry and cold. Who can nourish the deficient?

Only the Dao-bearing ones.
The *Zhuangzi* says: The ancient sages took care of the old, weak, orphans, and widows, ensuring all were provided for.
Thus, the sages
The *Zhuangzi* says: The ancients were complete—they nurtured all things, and their benevolence extended to the people.

They act without claiming merit,
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: The Dao of Heaven and Earth—all things rely on it for existence, yet none know its virtue.
Their work accomplished, they take no credit,
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: The Dao of Heaven and Earth—all things complete their work without dwelling on it, yet none know its virtue.
They do not seek to be seen as virtuous.
The *Tongxuan Jing* says: The sage is empty of self, seeing only insufficiency. Seeing insufficiency, they achieve true virtue.

**Chapter 78: The Gentle and Weak of the World**
The *Tongxuan Jing* speaks: The sea does not reject the smallest streams to become great; the forests do not reject the crooked and bent to flourish. chunks.original_text: 柔弱微眇，故能成其高，功名自化。 言：受国之垢，是谓社稷主； 《通玄经》曰：古者圣人不求可非之行，不憎人之非己，举世非之而不加沮。 受国之不祥，是谓天下王。 《通玄经》曰：古者圣人使人诽谤於己者，心之过也。 言出於口，不可止於人； 行发於近，不可禁於远。 正言若反。 《通玄经˙上仁篇》曰：后世有言者穷之以辞，有谏者诛之以罪，如此而欲求海内存万方，其离聪明亦以远矣。 和大怨章第七十九 此章《通玄经》言：和大怨必有余怨，奈何其为不善也。 古者亲近不以言，来远不以言，使近者悦，远者来。 与民同欲则和，与民同守则固，与民同念者知，得民力者富，得民誉者显。 末世行有召贼，言有致祸，无先人言，后人已附之。 耳流闻千里者，祸也。 舌者，机也，出言不当，驷马不追。 此劝战国和其怨，言罢兵不争，天下太平，乃为善也。 和大怨， 《通玄经˙微明篇》曰：古者和大怨，有德司契，不争为善也。 必有余怨，安可以为善？ 《通玄经》曰：战国无道，作难结怨，必有余怨，奈何其为不善也。 是以圣人 《南华经》曰：古之圣人其备乎，和天下。 执左契， 《通玄经》曰：阴害物，阳化物。 圣人之道，依阳天下和同，依阴天下怨恶。 而不责於人。 《通玄经》曰：其怨大者，其祸深。 畜怨而无息者，未尝有也。 故有德司契， 《通玄经》曰：积德成王，积石成山。 不积而成，未之有也。 无德司彻。 《通玄经》曰：积怨成亡，积水成河。 不积而成，未之有也。 天道无亲，常与善人。 《通玄经》曰：天道无亲，惟德是与。 小国寡民章第八十 此章《南华经□胠箧篇》言：昔者大道至德之世，容成氏，大庭氏、伯皇氏、中央氏、栗陆氏、骊畜氏、赫胥氏、尊卢氏、祝融氏、伏羲氏、神农氏、轩辕氏，当是时也，民结绳而用之，甘其食，美其服，安其居，乐其俗，邻国相望，鸡犬之音相闻，民至老死而不相往来。 若此之时，结绳质朴，天下太平则至治矣。 小国寡民， 《通玄经˙符言篇》曰：得万人之兵，不如闻一言之当； 得隋侯之珠，不如得事之所由； 得和氏之璧，不如得事之所适。 天下虽大，好用兵者亡； 国家虽安，好战者危。 故小国寡民，使有什伯之器而不用。 使有什伯之器而不用， 《洞灵经》曰：古先圣王之所以茂耕识者，以为本教也，劝民农地产也。 使民重死而不远徙。 《通玄经》曰：古者伏羲氏之王天下也，其德生而不杀。 当此之时，无利害之心，天下太平。 虽有舟舆，无所乘之， 《南华经》曰：古者神农之世，卧则居居，起则于于，民知其母不知其父，与麋鹿共处，无有相害之心，此至德之隆也。 虽有甲兵，无所陈之， 《通玄经》曰：黄帝之治天下，理日月之精，治阴阳之气，节四时之度，正律历之数，辨男女，明上下，田者让畔，道不拾遗。 使民复结绳 《南华经》曰：昔者三皇之世，民结绳而用之。 而用之。 《南华经》曰：上古大道至德之世，无为也，则用天下而有余治。 上无为也，下亦无为也。 甘其食， 《南华经》曰：古者之民，昼拾橡栗，甘其食也，故命之曰知生之民。 美其服， 《南华经》曰：古者之民，不知衣服，夏多积薪，冬则炀之，美其服也，故命之曰知生之民。
